DOC.HEAD: Man Attacked and Killed by Polar Bear in Eskimo Village
DOC.TEXT: A polar bear attacked and killed a man as he walked with his girlfriend through a tiny Eskimo village on the Arctic Coast, officials said. Officials later tracked down the bear and destroyed it, said U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service spokesman Bruce Batten. He said officials were speculating that the bear attacked the man because it was hungry, Batten said. An autopsy on the victim, 28-year-old Carl Stalker, was to be held in Fairbanks. Federal wildlife officials planned to examine the bear's remains for possible clues to the attack. Stalker was killed early Saturday in Point Lay, a village of about 160 residents some 200 miles southwest of Barrow and 700 miles northwest of Anchorage. His girlfriend, who has not been publicly identified, was not injured. Such polar bear attacks are rare, Batten said. ``We're extremely interested in finding out what we can find out about this particular bear,'' he said. Polar bears migrate from east to west at this time of year, and during the winter months their principal source of food is seal meat, said Batten. Unlike brown and black bears in southern latitudes, male polar bears do not hibernate and spend most of the winter hunting for food. ``They tend to be rather curious and will often be attracted by motion or activity,'' said Batten. He said some polar bears have been attracted by smell of garbage at dumps and can create a nuisance in villages and larger towns.

Museum Pronounces van Gogh Portrait the Real Thing
DOC.TEXT: Museum officials locked in a battle with an art critic over the authenticity of a purported self-portrait by van Gogh say they have new proof, contained in an X-ray of the painting. The X-ray, taken at Hartford's Mount Sinai Hospital, shows the outlines of a sketch beneath the painting, and officials at Wadsworth Atheneum say the sketch was clearly done by van Gogh in the mid-1880s. ``With these scientific results, we now have what I believe is `the smoking pistol' - positive proof that this must be a work by Vincent van Gogh,'' said museum Director Patrick McCaughey. The X-ray and the picture will be exhibited side-by-side on Tuesday at the museum. The authenticity of the 16-by-13-inch painting has been challenged repeatedly since it was donated to the museum in 1954 by architect Philip Goodwin. Museum officials have maintained it is one of a series of gaunt, haunting self-portraits van Gogh painted in 1886 through 1888. Most recently, Swiss art dealer and critic Walter Feilchenfeldt insisted the work is a forgery or, more likely, a van Gogh portrait painted in tribute by another artist. He said the painting ``is not van Gogh's style.'' The painting is to be included in an international exhibition next year. ``The international exhibition is what really propelled us into saying, `Let's sort this painting out once and for all,''' McCaughey said. ``Let's see if it is worth $17 million or $1.70 - $1.70 being the value of the frame.'' The museum said the X-ray disclosed a sketch of a fleshy woman in a bonnet. The woman looks much like the figures in van Gogh's series of pictures of Dutch peasants, such as ``The Potato Eaters,'' McCaughey said. ``When the X-ray was turned upside down, there indeed was Mrs. Potato Eater, or Miss Potato Eater, seated at the pail peeling her spuds,'' he said. Impoverished artists like van Gogh painted over earlier works or painted on both sides of a canvas to save money. McCaughey said it is extremely unlikely a forger would have gone to the trouble of forging an additional van Gogh underneath the portrait. Feilchenfeldt said of the findings, ``This is, of course, exciting news, about the X-ray, which I have not seen. But I am more inclined to believe that these images found underneath could also be forgeries.'' The critic has also challenged the authenticity of van Gogh self-portraits owned by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and Norway's National Gallery in Oslo.

DOC.HEAD: Bethlehem 1990: Nothing But Room At The Inn
DOC.TEXT: In the season of Christmas pilgrimages by Christians from around the world, the town where Jesus was born has nothing but room at its inns. Mayor Elias Freij looks out the window of his office onto the deserted square at the Church of the Nativity. ``Tourists? What tourists?'' he asks rhetorically, sweeping an arm toward the emptiness. ``This is the worst situation in my memory.'' ``With the drums of war beating in the Saudi desert and the large armada assembling in the (Persian) gulf, people are simply too scared to come here,'' says Freij, a Greek Orthodox Palestinian who has been mayor for 18 years. He said ``the last straw'' was Israel's decision in October to distribute gas masks in case of an Iraqi attack. ``Would you go on holiday to a country where you need a gas mask?'' Freij asked. Israel has suffered an overall loss in tourism because of the gulf crisis. Bethlehem and Arab east Jerusalem are especially affected because the crisis accompanies what usually is their busiest season. The government had predicted a record year in tourism, surpassing the previous high of 1.5 million visitors in 1987. Instead, tourist arrivals have declined by half since Iraq seized Kuwait on Aug. 2, said Tourism Ministry spokesman Yossi Shoval. He said the 1990 total would be 1.3 million at best. Shoval said the ministry still was trying to woo Jewish religious groups and Christians pilgrims, but that Israel had canceled its overseas television advertising ``until the gulf situation improves.'' ``There will be Christians here for Christmas,'' he said. ``The question is how many.'' On a recent morning in Bethlehem, a single tour bus was parked in Manger Square. Its seven Italian passengers were alone in the underground grotto of the Church of the Nativity, kneeling at the silver star that marks the site of Christ's birth. In normal times, pilgrims would be elbow-to-elbow in the church and the tiny grotto. ``Things are so bad that I am not earning enough to feed me and my wife,'' said Issa el-Boyaji, a man in his 70s who usually makes his living shining the shoes of pilgrims outside the church. He has set aside his brass-inlaid shoeshine box and directs drivers into parking places around Manger Square, hoping they will give him small change for his efforts. Traditional religious ceremonies are scheduled for the holidays. They will begin on Christmas Eve with the ceremonial arrival of the Roman Catholic patriarch of Jerusalem and end with Masses and Anglican chorale services. For the fourth year, Bethlehem will forgo street decorations and holiday receptions in sympathy with the Palestinian uprising in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, Freij said. The revolt against Israeli occupation, which began in December 1987, has taken the lives of more than 770 Palestinians and 53 Israelis. ``With the confrontations, with the desperation, there is nothing to celebrate,'' the mayor said. The drop in tourism has taken its toll on the economy of Bethlehem, a town of 40,000 people. Freij says only one of the six hotels is operating and nearly all the 80 restaurants are closed. Scores of craftsmen have been laid off at the 400 workshops that produce olive wood carvings and mother-of-pearl jewelry. Tax collections have fallen off so much, Freij said, that municipal workers could not be paid in November. Fahmi Nashashibi, secretary of the Arab Hotels Association in Jerusalem and Bethlehem, said he had closed two of his three hotels for pilgrims in east Jerusalem because more than half the Christmas bookings were canceled.

DOC.HEAD: Former Panamanian Diplomat Reportedly Focus of Tapes Probe
DOC.TEXT: The FBI investigation into who leaked tapes of Manuel Noriega's prison phone calls focuses on a political opponent who might testify against the deposed Panamanian dictator, newspapers reported. The FBI believes the source of the leak appears to be Jose Blandon, once an intelligence officer in Panama for Noriega and the country's former consul general in New York, The Miami Herald and The Washington Post reported, quoting unidentified sources. Blandon denied leaking the government tapes. In an interview published Sunday in The Post, Blandon said someone in the U.S. government who wants to sabotage the Noriega trial must have been responsible. ``Somebody in the government was leaking them,'' Blandon said. Drug enforcement agents were present whenever he had access to the tapes, and he was allowed to make only written notes, Blandon said. Blandon also said he provided prosecutor Patrick Sullivan with a written summary of the tapes at Sullivan's request. That summary referred to several calls between Noriega and his lead defense attorney, Frank Rubino, Blandon said. ``I mentioned everything,'' Blandon said, including a conversation in which Noriega and Rubino discussed how to deal with Luis del Cid, a former Noriega aide who has pleaded guilty in the case and promised to testify against his former boss. The FBI is trying to determine who gave the tapes to Cable News Network, which aired some of Noriega's conversations from prison over the past month. The broadcasts were halted briefly while a federal judge decided whether Noriega's right to a fair trial would be jeopardized. After reviewing the tapes, the judge decided to let CNN broadcast them. A spokesman for the U.S. attorney's office in Miami said prosecutors have not listened to any of the tapes, and would neither confirm nor deny that prosecutors received Blandon's summary of the tapes he reviewed. FBI agents searched Blandon's home in Houston on Thursday night looking for telephone logs and documents, both newspapers reported. Unidentified sources said Blandon played portions of the tapes for two officials of the Panamanian government in a Miami hotel room in March, the Herald said Saturday. If the FBI can prove Blandon leaked the tapes, or if the court determines that prosecutors have been tainted by exposure to privileged conversations between Noriega and his attorneys, the government's efforts to try Noriega on drug charges could be hampered. Blandon has been considered a key government witness since he testified before a Senate committee in 1988 that Noriega protected U.S.-bound cocaine shipments. Blandon's role in reviewing the tapes was revealed after the government confirmed publicly for the first time in court documents Friday that DEA agents had studied Noriega's phone calls. Noriega is awaiting trial on charges of taking $4.6 million in payoffs to protect the cocaine trade passing through Panama from Colombia to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Driver Who Thought He Could Drive Through Cars Sets Off Collisions
DOC.TEXT: A man who claimed God told him he could drive through cars with his flatbed truck hit 18 vehicles and injured about 12 people Saturday, authorities said. A 2- to 3-mile section of the Nimitz Freeway between Hayward and San Leandro was littered with dented vehicles before Emmet Wheat, 47, hit the center divider with his truck, police said. Most seriously injured was 8-year-old Francesca Camus of Hayward, who was listed in critical condition at Childrens Hospital in Oakland, authorities said. Camus was ejected from her mother's van when it was struck by the truck, highway patrol officials said. The other injuries were minor, officials said. The accidents closed a half-mile section of the highway east of San Francisco Bay for about two hours. Wheat, owner of Commercial Auto Wreckers in San Leandro, was booked for investigation of felony hit-run driving and driving under th influence of alcohol. He was not injured. His wife, Karen, said she spoke to her husband over the truck's radio just after he rammed into the center divider. ``He said the Lord had spoken to him and that the Lord told him he could drive though the cars,'' she said. ``He's been talking about this kind of stuff a lot lately,'' she said. ``I didn't know he was this bad. I thought he wanted attention.'' Highway patrol officers said they found rambling religious messages signed ``Emmet and the Lord'' on the truck.

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop Tutu Urges Iraq, U.S. to Talk, Not Fight
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Iraq should avert war in the Persian Gulf by talking out their differences, South African Archbishop Desmond Tutu said Saturday. ``People must make it more and more clear that we are peacemongers, because peace is so sensible. It's so much more sensible than war,'' said the Anglican prelate, who won the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize for his opposition to South African apartheid. At a news conference, Tutu also urged the United States to continue its economic sanctions against South Africa ``until the process of dismantling apartheid is irreversible.'' Apartheid is South Africa's official police of racial segregation and discrimination against non-whites. Although South Africa's President F.W. de Klerk deserves credit for some reform, ``the pillars of apartheid still stand firmly in place,'' Tutu said. Tutu came to this ity of 24,000 people to help raise scholarship money for South African students abroad and for American Indian students in Montana. Tutu heads the 2.6 million-member Anglican Church of Southern Africa. This was his only scheduled stop in North America while en route to a convocation in Honduras. The visit was arranged by the Montana Logging and Ballet Company, a Helena-based quartet that mixes music, comedy and satire to promote political and social causes. Tutu wrote liner notes for the group's latest album after hearing it perform an anti-apartheid song, ``Take the Barriers Down,'' in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Man Jailed for Kicking Police Horse
DOC.TEXT: A horse is not always just a horse - sometimes he's a large police officer. That's what a judge said when sentencing a Raleigh man to one year in prison for assaulting a police officer by kicking Heir Apparent, a Raleigh police horse. ``I can't condone assault on a law officer by kicking his horse,'' Judge James Fullwood said Friday after sentencing Elijah Lawrence. ``You created a threat to others as evidenced by you hauling off and kicking the horse.'' On Oct. 15, Officer D.A. Brugger was trying to arrest Lawrence for failing to appear in court when the man kicked the horse twice in the thigh. The horse reared but wasn't seriously hurt. Lawrence was arrested when a police patrol car arrived. ``There was no defense,'' said Lawrence's attorney, Tim Blake. ``He kicked it and the officer said, `Don't kick it.' and he kicked him again.'' It wasn't immediately known why Lawrence was to appear in court in the first place or why he allegedly failed to appear.

DOC.HEAD: Yolanda King Snubs Arizona at Last Minute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with nine grafs to UPDATE that understudy will replace Ms. King, details on play, moves up background on controversy. Picks up last graf pvs, `Tucson, Phoenix...'
DOC.TEXT: Yolanda King, daughter of slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr., on Saturday canceled her Arizona appearance in a musical play scheduled for the next day. Ms. King, 34, and Attallah Shabazz, the daughter of black activist Malcolm X, partners in the performing arts group Nucleus, scheduled the performance months before Arizona voters narrowly rejected two referendums which would have created paid state holidays to honor King. An understudy from New York would replace Ms. King in ``Stepping Into Tomorrow,'' scheduled to be performed at the University of Arizona Sunday afternoon, said Tani Sanchez, a university spokeswoman. The other eight performers would hold a news conference in Tucson Sunday, Ms. Sanchez said in a statement announcing Ms. King's withdrawal. Ms. King would supply a statement but would not attend the news conference, she said. Ms. King considered canceling in the aftermath of the Nov. 6 vote. Many conventions were canceled and NFL Commissioner Paul Tagliabue has recommended moving the 1993 Super Bowl out of Arizona because of the rejection. She and Ms. Shabazz said last week that they would go ahead with the performance in hopes of furthering King's ideals. Jahna Cole, Ms. King's Van Nuys, Calif.-based publicist, declined to say why she pulled out at the last minute. Ms. King and Ms. Shabazz wrote and co-direct the musical, which examines issues such as teen pregnancy, drug abuse, peer pressure and education. Tucson, Phoenix and more than 20 other Arizona cities celebrate King's Jan. 15 birthday with paid holidays for their municipal employees. The state honors King on the third Sunday in January with an unpaid state holiday. Most activists scoff at the unpaid holiday.

DOC.TEXT: Twenty-three Americans headed for home Sunday after flying out of Baghdad as the first to depart since Iraq announced it is freeing all foreign captives. One of the 23 shouted jubilantly: ``We're outta here!'' The group was headed for Houston early Sunday after a brief stopover in Shannon, Ireland, aboard a Boeing 707 jetliner chartered by former Treasury Secretary John Connally, according to airport officials in Shannon. Two British hostages, also on the plane that left Baghdad on Saturday, got off at Shannon. The plane was expected to arrive in Houston early Sunday. It was not clear whether the departure of Connally's mission had been arranged before the Iraqi parliament on Friday approved President Saddam Hussein's call to free the hostages. The exodus was expected to get under way in earnest on Sunday. President Bush, in Venezuela, welcomed the move to free the captives, but said Iraq still must get out of Kuwait, which it overran Aug. 2. ``When you don't have Americans there, and if force is required, that's just one less worry I've got,'' Bush said. Iraqi authorities, meanwhile, called on the public Saturday to ``renew their vigilance'' in the face of a possible threat from the U.S.-led international forces. The Interior Ministry had instructed civil defense groups and provincial officials to prepare for ``any eventuality,'' said the nightly television news broadcast. Posters warning the population ``not to panic in case of attack'' appeared on walls of buildings in downtown Baghdad. In London, the Observer newspaper reported Sunday that Iraq has redrawn its border with Kuwait and could withdraw as early as next month. The Observer, in a story from Washington, said Iraq was laying claim to an area of the Rumaila oilfield and the islands of Warba and Bubiyan in the Persian Gulf. The report, citing unidentified Arab sources in Washington, said Iraq has erected a barbed-wire fence around the southern tip of the oilfield, which extends into northern Kuwait. Iraq has long claimed the area. Iraqi officials said Saturday all the departing detainees still need exit visas. U.S. officials have asked them to expedite the processing. Americans who had been held at strategic installations as ``human shields'' began arriving in Baghdad Saturday. Many said they would not feel safe until they were out of Iraq. ``I still think of myself as a hostage because I cannot leave the hotel,'' said Edward Smiley of Los Angeles. Smiley, who said he was moved around to six different locations, described conditions as ``very bad.'' He said the hostages were forced to sleep in bug-ridden beds and to eat fish heads for much of the time. About 8,000 Westerners had been detained since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, including about 600 who were held at stratgic sites in an effort to deter any U.S. attack. The hostages included about 900 Americans as well as other Westerners, Eastern Europeans and Japanese. The first group of 17 American hostages was led through passport control at Baghdad's Saddam Airport by Iraqi officials. ``We're outta here!'' shouted a delighted American. The airport departure area was littered with broken suitcases, clothes and other debris left over from a group of at least 200 Vietnamese workers flown to Hanoi earlier in the day. A witness who did not want to be named described how Iraqi customs officials tore through their luggage pulling out food, carpets and other items. The 23 Americans on the flight arranged by Connally also included members of the U.S. Embassy staff in Kuwait, and three people who had taken refuge at the ambassador's refuge in Baghdad. Connally went to Baghdad on a private mission to obtain the release of hostages. A group of 41 Japanese men whose release was approved before Sadam's announcemnt also flew to Amman, Jordan, on Saturday aboard an Iraqi Airways plane. They later left for Tokyo. Nur Eldin al-Safi, the head of Iraqi Airways, said the airline was prepared to fly out all of the hostages within three days if their travel documents are ready. He said that no foreign carrier would be allowed to transport them out of Iraq. Al-Safi said U.S. officials had chartered one of the airlines' Boeing 707s to fly to Kuwait Sunday to pick up Americans. The United States had also chartered a 747 jumbo jet to fly those Americans and others in Baghdad to Frankfurt, Germany, later Sunday, he added. Meanwhile, the official Iraqi News Agency said Iraq rejected the dates the United States has suggested for Secretary of State James A. Baker III's trip to Baghdad for talks with Saddam. Iraq proposed Jan. 12 as the date for the Baker trip, the news agency said. The State Department had suggested he visit on Dec. 20, Dec. 21, Dec. 22 or Jan. 3. A Jan. 12 date would come only three days before the deadline set down in a U.N. resolution demanding an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. The Security Council measure authorizes use of ``all necessary means'' to dislodge Iraq after that. At the United Nations, the Security Council late Saturday postponed discussion of a resolution calling for an eventual international peace conference on the Middle East. The council voted 9-4 to adopt a Soviet motion to postpone consideration of the resolution until Monday. The United States voted in favor of postponement, while France and China abstained. A U.S. veto would outrage Washington's Arab allies in the anti-Iraq coalition assembled in the Persian Gulf, but Israel will be equally angered if the resolution passes with a U.S. abstention or vote in favor.

DOC.BYLINE: Polls Open in Final Election Vote Between Walesa and Tyminski ^By JOHN DANISZEWSKI
DOC.TEXT: Poles voted Sunday for their first popularly elected president, choosing between a national icon, Lech Walesa, and an emigre businessman who didn't live in Poland until two months ago. Opinion polls showed the Solidarity chief and former shipyard electrician far ahead of the newcomer, Stanislaw Tyminski. But Tyminski's surprise elimination of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki in the first round of voting on Nov. 25 was so unexpected that few were willing to count him out entirely. Tyminski, 42, who owns a Toronto computer and communications business and leads the fringe Libertarian Party of Canada, began campaigning in October after 21 years in Toronto and Iquitos, Peru. Walesa, 47, voted after leaving Mass in his hometown, Gdansk, where Auxiliary Bishop Zygmunt Pawlowicz had greeted him as ``our dear Mr. President.'' The Roman Catholic church openly endorsed Walesa in the campaign. Polls opened at 6 a.m. and were to close at 8 p.m. (2 p.m. EST) Reliable projections of results were expected within minutes afterward based on exit polls conducted throughout the day by state television and the German polling service Infas. Temperatures were around the freezing mark, and snow covered the ground in the southern part of the country. More than 27 million Poles are eligible to cast their ballots at 22,000 polling stations nationwide. Spending freely and railing against the economic ``treason'' of the Mazowiecki government, Tyminski turned the campaign on its head in the first round of voting. But he has been hurt recently as new information surfaced regarding his links to members of the former Communist Party, his advocacy of nuclear weapons in a campaign tract and his reported use of hallucinogenic drugs in the Amazon jungle. The president will succeed Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the former Communist Party chief who imposed martial law on Solidarity nine year ago this week. The new president, who will serve a five-year term, will be in office while Poland drafts its new constitution next year. No date has been set for the swearing-in. If no challenges are raised to the official results, it could happen by the end of this week. Historically, Poland's presidents were always elected by parliament. Polls last week showed Walesa leading Tyminski by more than a 3-1 margin. Out of 13 people interviewed after polls opened in Warsaw, not one said they voted for Tyminski. However he was believed to have more support in rural areas. The presidency would cap an astonishing personal voyage for Walesa, who rose from his origins in a poor peasant family to become a shipyard electrician, then led the Solidarity trade union movement in the first peaceful revolution to dump a Communist government. Should Walesa win, goes a joke circulating here, Poland would become a true Communist state - with a worker as president.

DOC.HEAD: Former Texas Gov. Connally Brings Home 21 American Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT that 21 American hostages arrived in Houston; SUBS 8th graf, `Seven of...', to give background on 22nd hostage, a Briton who got off flight in Ireland.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HT1
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-one Americans held hostage by Iraq arrived in the United States early Sunday to the cheers of nearly 200 relatives and supporters. The chartered jet touched down at Ellington Field south of downtown Houston at 4:40 a.m. CST. The crowd, some waving small American flags, applauded and cheered as the hostages started down the stairway onto the tarmac. Once off the plane, they were escorted to the nearby U.S. Coast Guard hangar. ``God bless America!'' said former hostage Scott Nelson of Los Angeles. He said he was held at a munitions plant about 35 miles south of Baghdad, and was treated well. John Remington of Redondo Beach, Calif., who worked for an American architectural firm in Kuwait, said ``we were treated fine once you accept the fact that you're being held against your will.'' The Iraqi parliament on Friday approved President Saddam Hussein's call to free all foreign captives. The exodus was expected to get under way in earnest on Sunday. The hostages flew to Houston with John Connally, a former U.S. treasury secretary and former Texas governor, and Houston oilman Oscar Wyatt. The two flew to Baghdad last week with $500,000 worth of medical supplies as a goodwill gesture. Seven of the hostages' relatives and three U.S. Embassy employees were also on board the corporate jet. A 22nd hostage was also on board when the plane left Iraq, Peter McCleod, a British subject who got off during a refueling stop in Ireland. Connally, who had tears in his eyes as he watched the former hostages greet their relatives, said that he and Wyatt did not tell State Department officials about their planned trip to Baghdad, nor did they ask for their assistance in securing the hostages release. ``We knew they would try to discourage us,'' Connally said. ``We didn't want to be discouraged.'' Connally noted that State Department officials had discouraged hostages relatives from traveling to Baghdad. Wyatt is chairman of Coastal Corp., which provided the jet and paid for the medical supplies. The oil company also arranged Houston hotel rooms for the hostages' families and will provide flights home for the entire group, said Coastal spokesman Jim Bailey. None of the hostages works for Coastal, Bailey said. Wyatt and Connally secured the captives' release before Saddam announced that all foreigners would be released. Connally said he and Wyatt advised Saddam that a release of hostages at Christmastime would be a show of compassion. Connally said Saddam replied, ``you will not go home with an empty plane.'' But filling the plane became difficult because of bureaucratic delays in obtaining exit visas. Connally said that the hostages that accompanied him made it on this flight only because they were able to get clearance first. Wyatt said that the Iraqi government had donated $30,000 worth of fuel to fly the plane home because Wyatt was forbidden by U.S. economic sanctions to buy fuel directly from the Iraqis. About 8,000 Westerners had been detained since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, including about 600 who were held at strategic sites in an effort to deter any U.S. attack. The hostages included about 900 Americans as well as other Westerners, Eastern Europeans and Japanese. Former hostage Bill Rodebush of McAlester, Okla., said he was ``treated as good as they could'' but added he was moved six times during his captivity. He refused to say where he was held ``till all my friends get out.''

DOC.HEAD: Nationalist Group Targets Italian Villas on French Island
DOC.TEXT: Small gas bombs blew apart six vacation villas under construction, and a nationalist terrorist group claimed responsibility, police said Sunday. The villas, in a tourist complex in Poggio-Mezanna near this northern Corsican capital, were destroyed Saturday night in separate blasts, along with two cars bearing Italian license plates, police said. No one was injured in the explosions at the deserted site, where an Italian-Corsican company is building vacation homes. Nationalist inscriptions written in the Corsican language were found painted on battered walls along with the letter ``R'' - the signature of the terrorist group Resistenza, which has claimed responsibility for numerous attacks since it first appeared in September. Resistenza is an offshoot of the Corsican National Liberation Front (FLNC), which has long targeted vacation centers in its fight for independence for this French Mediterranean island. Eleven villas were destroyed on Friday in a similar incident near Calvi, also in northern Corsica.

DOC.HEAD: Bonnet From `Gone With The Wind' To Be Auctioned
DOC.TEXT: The black bonnet worn by Vivien Leigh as the tempestuous Scarlett O'Hara in ``Gone With The Wind'' will be auctioned this week, the auction house said Sunday. The actress wore the Christian Dior creation in the box office blockbuster and for publicity stills with co-star Clark Gable, who played Rhett Butler. When filming finished, Miss Leigh gave the hat to London theater critic Alan Dent, her close friend and biographer, a spokesman for Phillips auctioneers said. When Dent died in 1978, Scarlett's bonnet passed to an elderly couple in Cumbria county, northern England, who had given Dent a home after he retired. Phillips will auction it on Friday in Chester, 180 miles northwest of London, with some of Dent's letters and theater memorabilia, said the spokesman. John Hayes, a friend of the owners, said they wanted the hat ``to go to someone who will appreciate it.'' ``It is a unique piece of cinema history and I suppose it would be a good idea if it ended up in a museum devoted to the art.'' Phillips' specialists are reluctant to specify the value of the hat. ``Who knows what its value may be to a collector or museum,'' said Jeremy Lamond, of the collectors' department.

DOC.HEAD: Francis Albert Sinatra, Saloon Singer to American Legend, Turns 75
DOC.TEXT: Frank Sinatra, one-time idol of bobby-soxers who became a show business legend, evokes nostalgia these days, but as he turns 75, he's still doing it his way. Known as the Chairman of the Board, Ol' Blue Eyes, the Voice, just plain Frank or simply Sinatra, the crooner is belting out standards for still another generation of pop music fans. On Tuesday, the eve of Francis Albert Sinatra's 75th birthday celebration, the entertainer returns to an arena near his New Jersey hometown of Hoboken to begin a yearlong world tour designed to fulfill a lifetime yearning - performances in the Soviet Union and possibly China. After kicking off his Diamond Jubilee World Tour at the Meadowlands' Brendan Byrne Arena, Sinatra will gather with his family at a hotel for a private birthday celebration. ``There are no words that can truly describe Frank Sinatra - magic, charisma and talent - they still don't accurately capture the aura about him,'' said his former longtime publicist, Lee Solters. Sinatra, who first became popular in the 1940s, continues to get under our skin, whether he's performing before sellout audiences or singing from recordings, including two new boxed sets just released for Christmas. ``Fly Me to the Moon,'' ``Strangers in the Night,'' ``You Make Me Feel So Young,'' ``The Lady Is a Tramp,'' ``New York, New York,'' ``Summer Wind,'' ``I've Got You Under My Skin'' and ``My Way'' are Sinatra classics. He's won Grammys and Emmys. He collected a special Academy Award in 1945 for ``The House I Live In,'' a short about religious and racial tolerance, and the supporting actor Oscar for his role as Pvt. Angelo Maggio in ``From Here to Eternity.'' He's appeared in more than 50 movies, including ``Anchors Aweigh,'' ``On the Town,'' ``Guys and Dolls,'' ``The Tender Trap,'' ``High Society,'' ``Pal Joey,'' ``The Manchurian Candidate'' and ``Von Ryan's Express.'' His hairline has receded over the years, and his waist has thickened, but his light baritone has only grown deeper and richer. The blunt, aggressive son of immigrants has ld a lavish lifestyle and associated with people whose names could be found in FBI files. But for each story of him punching someone who had offended him, there was a story of loyalty and generosity to friends and strangers. He exudes vitality these days. Still, Sinatra may be thinking about his age. During a toast on an upcoming TV special, he lifts his glass and says: ``May you all live to be 400 years old, and may the last voice you hear be mine.'' Tina Sinatra, his daughter who helped edit the CBS-TV special ``Sinatra 75: The Best Is Yet to Come,'' to be broadcast next Sunday, conceded she was overwhelmed after going over details of her father's life. ``I was pretty well educated, pretty well aware of his career, because I've known him all my life, of course,'' she said. ``But when you do it in a consolidated time it is quite something. It's emotional. It's fascinating. It's overwhelming.'' Sinatra, who refuses most interviews, has had good press and bad press over the years. Asked about the entertainer's well-publicized run-ins with the media, Solters explained: ``He doesn't cater to the press, but at the same time he's not rude to them intentionally. He's his own man. He's much maligned. The press will take something and blow it out of proportion. ``The press can take a thread and make a garment.'' Sinatra isn't bashful and doesn't hesitate to speak his mind. Most recently, after George Michael complained about the tragedy of fame, Sinatra wrote an open letter to the pop star telling him to stop whining. ``Frank is a tiger - afraid of nothing, ready for anything,'' Robert Mitchum once said. ``He'll fight anything. Here's a frail, undersized little fellow with a scarred-up face who isn't afraid of the whole world.'' Sinatra has been married four times. A romance with Ava Gardner led to the end of his marriage to longtime sweetheart Nancy Barbato, who married him in 1939 and bore three children - Nancy, Frank Jr. and Christina. His tempestuous, on-again, off-again marriage to Gardner ended in 1953. His name was linked with Lana Turner and Lauren Bacall, and he was engaged briefly to Juliet Prowse, but he did not marry again until 19-year-old Mia Farrow came into his life more than a decade later. By that time, he was the firmly established head of ``The Rat Pack'' or the Clan, a group including Dean Martin, Joey Bishop, Sammy Davis Jr. and Peter Lawford. In 1971, saying he wanted room for reflection, he gave his ``farewell concert'' in Los Angeles. But his retirement ended two years later with a TV special, ``Ol' Blue Eyes is Back.'' In 1976, he married Barbara Marx, former wife of Zeppo Marx. Among those attending: Ronald Reagan. ``People often remark that I'm pretty lucky. I don't think luck as such has much to do with it,'' Sinatra said in a 1957 interview with The New York Times. ``You've got to have something more substantial. The competition is too fierce.'' The lyrics to ``My Way,'' his signature song, express it all for Sinatra: ``I've lived a life that's full. I traveled each and every highway. And more, much more than this - I did it my way.''

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Minister: Rushdie Death Decree Irrevocable
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian minister was quoted as saying Sunday that the death sentence against author Salman Rushdie is still valid and is irrevocable. Mohammad Khatami, minister of culture and Islamic guidance, made the comment in an interview with the Islamic Republic News Agency, carried by Tehran radio. The late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ``passed Islam's sentence against Salman Rushdie, and this decree, and under no circumstances can this be revoked,'' Khatami was quoted as saying. Rushdie has been in hiding since Khomeini called for his death in February 1989 for allegedly defaming Islam in his novel ``The Satanic Verses.'' Last week, Rushdie made a brief appearance at a London bookstore to sign copies of ``Haroun and the Sea of Stories,'' a children's book he wrote while in hiding. Tehran and London restored ties in September, 18 months after relations were broken over the Rushdie affair. Khatami's pronouncement was an apparent jab at President Hashemi Rafsanjani, whose success in downplaying Khomeini's Fatwa, or religious edict, led to the restoration of Tehran-London ties. While the rest of Rafsanjani's Cabinet favors his pragmatic policies, Khatami is one of the few ministers whose sympathies extend to the rival anti-Western radical faction. The radicals, led by Parliament Speaker Mehdi Karrubi and former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, want to continue to use the Rushdie affair to block normalization of ties with the West. The Society of Combatant Theologians, which groups various hard-liners together, also said in a statement Sunday that the death decree against Rushdie was irrevocable.

DOC.HEAD: Effects of Slump in Housing Industry Trickling Through Economy
DOC.TEXT: The effects of the weakening housing industry are trickling through the economy, touching not just carpenters and contractors but thousands of others not directly involved in building houses. For builder Dan Pincus, the downturn means slowing his Brick, N.J., operation from three or four houses under construction at one time to just one. For Doug Brackett of the American Furniture Manufacturers Association in High Point, N.C., it means slower furniture sales. ``When housing starts are down, furniture sales are down,'' explains Irene Kleeberg of the National Retail Federation in New York. ``That includes rugs and washing machines, dishwashers and mattresses.'' ``Houses are not being sold, and this affects retail sales,'' she continued. ``If you buy a new house, you want new furniture even if your old furniture is OK.'' The Commerce Department says housing starts plunged 6 percent in October to their lowest level since the 1981-82 recession. Starts were down 12.4 percent during the first 10 months of the year. Sales of new homes also were off 3.5 percent in October, matching the 1981-82 recession-level decline in housing starts. For the year, sales have fallen 15.8 percent from the same period of 1989. And the Labor Department reported on Friday that 62,000 more construction jobs were lost in November. Over the last six months, construction employment has dropped by about 250,000, the government said. Robert Villanueva, director of forecasting for the National Association of Home Builders, said the impact of a weakening housing industry spreads far beyond the construction industry. For every 1,000 houses being built, the total number of jobs involved is 1,759 man-years, he said. ``That means for one house, it's almost 1.8 years if one man built the house.'' But, Villanueva added, actual construction represents less than half of those jobs. In fact, construction man-years account for just 627 of the total, including 525 man-years involved in on-site work - ``the guy actually out there with a hammer.'' Other industries, including manufacturing building products, transportation and selling services, represent another 897 man-years, he said. Manufacturing alone accounts for about 23 percent of the total. Land develoment - ``clearing the land, trenching it, putting in the sewers and other utilities'' - accounts for yet another 235 man-years. At the same time, slackening demand has brought down prices - and presumably profits - in various industries. ``For example, gypsum prices ... showed about a 6 or 7 percent decline over the past year,'' Villanueva said. Gypsum is a primary material for interior walls of houses. ``Lumber and wood prices ... also seem to be sliding over the last six months,'' Villanueva added. He said sales of basic construction supplies peaked last February and have declined 5.5 percent since then. Sales of home furnishings such as appliances and air conditioners and furniture have declined 5.3 percent since their March high. Nevertheless, economist Sandra Shaber with the Futures Group in Washington says replacement demand is softening some of the effect of the housing slowdown. ``For certain demographic and economic reasons, replacement demand is somewhat stronger than it might otherwise be,'' she said. ``That's both because there's a very large group of aging baby boomers and the difficulties of the affordability of moving. ``While this in no way is going to save the appliance or furniture businesses from suffering during a recession, it can cushion some of the blow,'' she added. ``Appliances and furniture might have been even weaker had it not been for a certain amount of demographically and economically related replacement demand.'' In fact, Mary Gillespie of the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers in Chicago says her organization has been ``hard-pressed to put together a close correlation with appliances and the downturn in housing.'' Ms. Gillespie admitted that appliance sales have slowed, although that was anticipated because of the overall economic sluggishness. But the downturn has not been in the areas usually closely related to housing, she added. ``For example, ranges,'' she explained. ``Ranges are the first appliance, the primary appliance, that's tied to new housing. While housing is down, that, in fact, has not been the case for ranges, either gas or electric ... Dishwashers are usually closely tied to new housing. Dishwashers are up 1.4 percent for the year.''

DOC.HEAD: Glare of Publicity Buffets Secret Navy Plane, Pentagon Brass
DOC.TEXT: The unfolding story of Pentagon bungling in the A-12 stealth aircraft program has revealed more than just new details about the secret Navy attack plane that's been under wraps for more than six years. Emerging evidence of mismanagement in the $50 billion program also has shown clearly that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has failed to break a longstanding and embarrassing pattern of waste and deception in weapons procurement. The Pentagon inspector general and a Navy internal report last week said technical problems in producing the first prototype plane were papered over to keep the contract fees flowing. Excessive secrecy limited normal program reviews that may have tipped off Navy managers early on to the plane's problems. Now the plane is over budget, overweight and overdue. There is some doubt it ever will get off the drawing board. The A-12 isn't just any plane. It's the Navy's No. 1 aviation priority, envisioned as the latest U.S. warplane to be built with composite materials that limit radar reflections and thereby make it especially difficult to detect by enemy radar. It is supposed to replace the Navy's venerable A-6 carrier-based attack planes in the mid-1990s. But the Navy report last week confirmed for the first time that the plane may be nearly 8,000 pounds heavier than the original specifications required. The main problem, it said, is ``weight growth'' due to the thickness of the construction material needed to make the plane strong enough for landings on aircraft carriers. The House Armed Services Committee was scheduled to hold a public hearing Monday on the A-12's problems, with Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III to testify. Cheney, back from a European trip, also was expecting a report Monday from his top deputy on ``corrective recommendations.'' One of the key executives Cheney recruited to help reform the arms-buying process - John Betti, a former Ford Motor Co. vice president - was singled out by the Pentagon inspector general as a culprit in the A-12 fiasco. ``We find Mr. Betti's failure especially troublesome,'' the inspector general wrote in a report to Congress. Betti still has his job, but Vice Adm. Richard C. Gentz, the top Navy officer overseeing the program, was ordered to retire after the internal Navy report said Navy managers had failed to tell the top brass of mounting financial and technical problems in the A-12 program. Two other senior Navy officials were transferred to other jobs and formally censured. A major review of the program in April by high-level Pentagon officials, including Betti, failed to disclose the problems. Betti shrugged off a warning from one of his own staff members that the contractors were stumbling and that development costs were at least $1 billion over the projected $4.8 billion. Betti chose to believe the overly optimistic assessments of the contractors, McDonnell Douglas Corp. and General Dynamics Corp., both of St. Louis. After being briefed on the program review's conclusions - and not knowing they were misleading - Cheney publicly assured Congress that the A-12 was on track and within budget. He urged that 620 of the planes be bought for $52 billion. Just a few weeks later, on June 1, the contractors dropped their bombshell: The work was a year behind schedule and far over budget, and the plane could not meet certain performance standards. Shortly afterward, General Dynamics took a $450 million write-off on the program, and both contractors are pursuing claims with the Pentagon to recover some unanticipated expenses. They also want to restructure the contract. Al Spivak, a General Dynamics spokesman, said the company had no comment on the Navy report in which both contractors were accused of concealing information that would have tipped off the Navy leadership to the project's problems. ``We're still reviewing it and we have nothing more to say at this time,'' Spivak said Friday. McDonnell Douglas did not return a call seeking comment last week. The Navy's A-12 investigation said excessive secrecy helped hide the problems. For example, an internal progress report normally provided to the office of the Navy secretary was not written because there were too few people available with the necessary security clearances. In her report, Inspector General Susan J. Crawford said the Pentagon gave the contractors too much latitude, citing a Pentagon inspector team's January visit to the General Dynamics A-12 plant in Fort Worth, Texas. The inspectors agreed at the end of their visit to turn over their notes, which General Dynamics reviewed for security classification. One set of notes was lost; it later was determined to have contained no secret information. ``We question any procedure by which a contractor obtains access to, and control over, the work product of government personnel engaged in oversight duties,'' Ms. Crawford wrote.

DOC.HEAD: ``Mature Partnership'' With Latins Closer Now Than Before
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT:
Two decades ago, when Richard Nixon was still a relative newcomer in the White House, he said the United States needed a more ``mature partnership'' with Latin America. Four presidents later, Nixon's goal may finally have been achieved. After spending eight of the past 13 days in Latin America - two in Mexico and six in South America - Bush can boast that there is probably less tension in the relationship than at any time over the past generation. There is general agreement between the United States and Latin America on shared objectives, particularly on achieving prosperity through increased trade and investment. These are key elements of the ``Enterprise for the Americas Initiative'' that Bush promoted throughout his travels. The crowds greeting Bush were generally friendly but not huge. As Bush headed home on Saturday, he could take comfort in the fact that the angry mobs that used to stalk visiting American leaders were largely absent. The ``Yankee go home'' mentality nowadays is largely limited to student fringe groups. Nixon himself was witness to what was perhaps the angriest anti-American demonstration in Latin American history. It happened right here in 1958 when Nixon was, like George Bush used to be, vice president. Nixon barely escaped with his life. Eleven years later, when Nixon wanted to send Nelson Rockefeller to Venezuela as part of a fact-finding mission, the Venezuelans told Rockefeller to say home. Bush was able to spend 24 tranquil hours here Friday and Saturday. Venezuelans who look upon the United States as the enemy are diminishing in number, and the more benign view of Washington extends elsewhere in the region. In his visits to Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina and Chile, there was a relaxed camaraderie at almost every stop as opposed to the cold, formal encounters U.S. officials were accustomed to during periods of friction over such issues as human rights abuses. Bush was able to speak to the national legislatures in four countries almost without incident. Underscoring the more laid back approach, Bush went to rodeos in Mexico and Argentina and took a dip at an Uruguayan beach resort. The past week would have been almost care free were it not for the repeated intrusions of the Persian Gulf crisis. There are a number of factors contributing to Bush's ability to breeze through one of the most ambitious Latin American tours ever undertaken by an American president: -One is the end of the Cold War, during which the United States and Latin America rarely saw eye to eye on how to deal with the issue of Marxism. Beyond that, few Latins now look on Cuba as the answer and the U.S. as the problem. -Another is the historic embrace of democracy in the region. At times in the past, the United States seemed to waver in its support for democracy but no longer, and most Latins applaud the change. -In addition, a remarkable consensus has emerged throughout the hemisphere that Latin economic stagnation is attributable to closed economic systems which, in Bush's words, have ``smothered growth'' and benefited only those with the right political connections. The new breed of leaders, Bush said here Saturday, ``understands that the road to growth, jobs and rising income is through new investment, expanded trade and unleashing the energy of entrepreneurs.'' Bush brought little with him except encouragement. At each stop, he reaffirmed his policy of trying to induce the Latins to stick to their new policies by offering them incentives in the areas of trade, investment and debt. His ultimate goal is a hemisphere-wide free trade agreement. U.S. officials wonder whether the Latins have the political will to carry out the reforms they agree are necessary. The Latins wonder whether Bush's trade goals will be thwarted by protectionist sentiment back home. How these issues are dealt with will have a bearing on both hemispheric harmony and prosperity.
-----
EDITOR'S NOTE: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for the Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Lung Cancer Increasing Sharply In Women Who Don't Smoke
DOC.TEXT: Lung cancer rates have climbed so sharply in the United States that the death rate from the disease among non-smoking women is now higher than the total lung cancer death rate in women 30 years ago, a study shows. ``Cancer is increasing in industrial countries above and beyond that due to cigarette smoking or aging alone,'' said Devra Lee Davis, an author of the study and one of the editors of a collection of studies exploring the recent increases in cancer. The increased rate of lung cancer among women who don't smoke could reflect exposure to second-hand cigarette smoke as well as exposure to radon, asbestos and possibly air pollution, said Davis, a researcher at the National Academy of Sciences in Washington. According to National Cancer Institute figures, the lung cancer death rate among all women in 1955 was 5.1 deaths per hundred thousand women. Davis and her collaborators calculated that the death rate in women non-smokers by 1985 was 6.1 per hundred thousand; the total reported lung cancer death rate that year for women was 26.4. Sharp increases are also occurring in brain cancer, a blood cancer called multiple myeloma and the dangerous skin cancer called melanoma, Davis said. And the increases are occurring in many industrial countries, not just the United States. ``The changes ar so great over such a short time in so many countries in men and women that we need to look carefully for their causes,'' she said. ``These could be very important as clues for prevention. And it's better to prevent cancer than to cure it.'' Although the studies emphasize occupational and environmental exposure, smoking remains one of the single most important causes of cancer, Davis said. In many industrial countries, it is responsible for 40 percent of all cancer deaths in men and 30 percent in women. Smoking kills an estimated 3 million people each year around the world, and if current trends continue that will climb to more than 10 million per year by 2020, she said. The new studies are collected in ``Trends in Cancer Mortality in Industrial Countries,'' which will be released by the New York Academy of Sciences later this week. A copy was obtained by The Associated Press. In addition to the increase in lung cancer among women non-smokers, Davis mentioned these other examples of cancer on the rise: - Multiple myeloma appears to be increasing in industrialized countries, possibly as a result of increasing exposure to benzene in gasoline, although that is not yet scientifically proven. ``If I had to bet, I'd bet it was true,'' said Dr. Bernard Goldstein of the University of Medicine and Dentistry in New Jersey, whose study suggested the link. ``I thought that communicating this would be of value because it would alert other investigators to look at their myeloma cases.'' - Melanoma is increasing in men much more rapidly than in women, suggesting some occupational exposure. ``Melanoma has been associated in some groups of workers with exposure to PCBs,'' said Davis. ``There are a number of cancers where men have higher rates than women,'' she said. For example, ``more men than women die of colo-rectal cancer, and their deaths from colo-rectal cancer are increasing faster for men than women,'' she said. ``When you see it elevated in men, you have to consider whether occupational factors are involved.'' Brain cancer in men and women and breast cancer are also rising dramatically, Davis said. The rise in the cancer rates and death rates is clear, Davis said. But she emphasized that the links to benzene, PCBs and other environmental carcinogens remain speculative. Many factors could play a role in the cancer increases, she said. They include a genetic predisposition to cancer; lifestyle, including drinking and smoking; the rate of consumption of anti-cancer foods like fresh fruits and vegetables; exposure to X-rays and infectious agents; and other occupational and environmental factors, she said. The studies to be released this week were first presented in Italy last year at a meeting of the Collegium Ramazzini, an honorary society of the world's leading authorities of occupational and environmental causes of disease.

DOC.HEAD: Glenn Bypasses Ethics Hearing for Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Sen. John Glenn last week derided the administration's Persian Gulf policy, went to secret Intelligence Committee briefings on the crisis and warned about a shortage of combat medical personnel. What the Ohio Democrat didn't do was attend the Senate Ethics Committee hearing investigating the ties he and four other senators had with savings and loan executive Charles H. Keating Jr. ``I have a job to do,'' Glenn said. ``Why waste time sitting down there?'' In fact, the Ohio Democrat has skipped nearly every ethics committee session dealing with the so-called Keating Five. Instead, he relies mainly on briefings from his lawyer. His last appearance was Nov. 16, when he issued a defiant defense: ``John Glenn does not peddle influence. Period.'' The five senators intervened with federal banking regulators on behalf of Keating, former head of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan. They also received $1.3 million in political donations for their campaigns and causes from Keating and his associates. All the senators have denied that the contributions influenced their intervention, and say their discussions with federal regulators on Keating's behalf amounted to routine help for a constituent. The special counsel prosecuting the case has recommended that Glenn and Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., be dropped from the case. Glenn is hardly alone in skipping the televised hearings. McCain and Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., have made brief appearances to watch testimony by their aides and a character witness. Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., last attended Nov. 20 and is said by a spokeswoman to be monitoring testimony from his office, where he's planning an agenda for the Senate Banking Committee, which he chairs. Sen. Alan Cranston is in California undergoing radiation treatment for prostate cancer. But Glenn has been the most conspicuous by his presence elsewhere on Capitol Hill. With the massive troop deployment and threat of war in the Persian Gulf, his committee assignments and longtime interest in nuclear proliferation have given him plenty to do. ``I think my first responsibility is doing whatever I can right here,'' Glenn said. ``I have a background in the military and I think on the Armed Services Committee people do listen to what I have to say,'' he said. ``I don't know why people think we should be sitting down in that (ethics) room all the time when we could be going to war.'' Last week, while the ethics committee hearing was being televised live on one cable channel, Glenn could be seen on two other channels. From his perch in the Senate Armed Services Committee hearing room, Glenn peered down at Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and criticized the Bush administration policy in the Persian Gulf. He called it a ```Chicken Little' approach ... the sky is falling and the only option is war.'' Cheney had told the committee that economic sanctions alone might not be enough to force Saddam Hussein from Kuwait. Glenn also asked Lt. Gen. William Odom, former director of the National Security Agency, about munitions supplies and troop rotations, and whether ``the American people are willing to support going to war.'' A few days later, on ABC-TV's ``Nightline'' program, he sounded alarms about severe shortages of combat doctors and nurses throughout the Department of Defense. ``Look, this nation may be going to war,'' Glenn said in an interview. ``Can anyone tell me any more important thing to be doing than making whatever input I can? That's what I've been doing.'' The military manpower subcommittee Glenn heads is looking into whether the Persian Gulf buildup will require a change in the nation's long-term plan for reducing the number of people in uniform. He's an expert on nuclear arms and he puts out a newsletter, ``Proliferation Watch.'' This month the publication annotated current knowledge on Iraq, which the Bush administration claims is trying to build a nuclear weapon. Glenn's reserved seat at the ethics proceeding also was empty while he conducted a classified intelligence hearing ``in which we looked into the nuclear claims of the administration.'' Glenn, who hasn't announced what his political plans will be when his term expires in 1992, says he's aware of how much is at stake for him. But he also says he would deserve to be criticized if he dropped everything to attend the entire ethics proceeding that began Nov. 15. ``To think you have to sit there every second of every day ... that's not what a Senate job is about,'' Glenn said. ``That's not a good use of my time.''

DOC.HEAD: Corruption, Distribution Problems Tying Up Badly Needed Food Supplies
DOC.TEXT: The KGB said Sunday it had uncovered plots to divert food from empty stores and hungry Soviet people, and said it was filing criminal charges against those responsible. Soviet media, meanwhile, said donated foreign food was waiting in cargo ships on the east and west coasts because of port congestion, and was piled up at Moscow railway stations due to a shortage of trucks and drivers. The KGB created a special unit last month to control distribution of donated food supplies and prevent their theft, after the government put it in charge of the ``battle against economic sabotage.'' The official Tass news agency reported Sunday that the KGB had ``exposed and stopped the actions of some officials aimed at obtaining personal advantages at the expense of state interests during the storage, transportation and selling to the population of foodstuffs and consumer goods.'' Some Western donors had expressed fears that their food aid could be diverted to the black market, siphoned off by corrupt officials or left to rot because of inefficient Soviet transportation and storage facilities. ``We held Moscow against the Nazis in late 1941, but now it seems we have given it up to our home predators who have caught their prey in their Mafia trade net,'' Stanislav Kondrashov, a respected Soviet commentator, wrote in the government newspaper Izvestia. Tass said the KGB discovered that a warehouse in the Novgorod region southwest of Leningrad planned to trade more than 160 tons of powdered milk for furniture from an unnamed foreign firm. The warehouse received the furniture, worth $55,000, and sold it to its employees instead of distributing it to local stores, Tass said. The KGB stopped the other half of the exchange, the illegal export of the milk worth $250,000, Tass said. The KGB also discovered that three to five tons of meat were being diverted daily from a meat plant in the Ukrainian city of Kharkov to a factory where it was made into sausages for sale on the black market. In addition, it found about seven tons of rice buried in the Kara-Kalpak Autonomous Region of the Uzbekistan Republic, Tass said. ``Numerous other cases of incomplete deliveries, concealment of imported and Soviet-made foodstuffs and manufactured goods, as well as speculation with those goods were exposed,'' Tass said. ``Criminal proceedings are being instituted against the offenders,'' it said. Soviet officials maintain that food production is no lower than last year, and many blame the barren store shelves on a crumbling distribution system and panicked consumers. Many republics and regions across the nation have halted shipments of food and consumer goods to Moscow and other areas to protest policies of the central government and keep scarce goods for themselves. Hundreds of tons of food and medicine have been arriving in Moscow in recent weeks from the United States, Germany, Italy, Israel, Britain, Switzerland and elsewhere. Much of the donations have come from private groups. Tass reported Sunday that congestion at ports on the east and west coasts was delaying the unloading of foreign food. Ships containing flour, sugar, meat and other food from Germany, Belgium and Cuba were backed up at Leningrad's port. ``The situation at Far Eastern ports is especially difficlt,'' Tass said without elaborating. The Communist Party newspaper Pravda quoted Nikolai Gavryushin, head of container and commercial traffic in the Railways Ministry, as saying the organization of unloading goods at Moscow railway stations was ``catastrophic.'' He said as of Saturday, there were 20,000 cargo containers and 300 railway cars with consumer goods and industrial equipment waiting to be unloaded. He said 101 rail cars with foreign meat have been standing at the Moscow-Tovarnaya cargo station since Nov. 25. Gavryushin blamed a shortage of trucks, drivers and storage space. ``All warehouses of trading establishments are packed to capacity,'' he said. ``On the other hand, shop shelves are empty. Why?''

DOC.HEAD: Politics, Economy on Agenda at GOP Governors Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Republican governors gathered on Sunday for a two-day conference on the political lessons of 1990 and the headaches of governing what they won. The economy is slumping, state budgets face a worsening squeeze, and the voters already have rebelled against tax increases - six states rejected incumbent governors in the Nov. 6 elections, and eight more switched parties in replacing retiring governors. For most of the governors who lost, tax increases were a major problem. For those who won, some of them with anti-tax campaign themes, budget woes will be an early challenge. Vice President Dan Quayle heads the list of administration officials coming to address the governors and to meet with them in private sessions. But the administration isn't likely to have much help to offer for their budget woes, since the federal government is in the same tax and spending vise that is squeezing states. There will be 20 Republican governors, 28 Democrats, two independents next year. Fourteen governors and four governors-elect were due at the conference. One Republican was coming with an aseerisk by his name: J. Fife Symington of Arizona narrowly led in the Nov. 6 election, but he didn't get a majority and so faces a Feb. 26 runoff against Democrat Terry Goddard. Politics was the conference keynote, with the governors conferring first with leaders of the Republican National Committee. William J. Bennett, newly designated to become party chairman, was due in his dual role - that one and as outgoing director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy. Florida Gov. Bob Martinez, defeated for re-election, is taking over the drug policy job. He was not at the conference. Formal sessions begin Monday morning, with appearances by Bennett, Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan and Environmental Protection Administration head William Reilly. Quayle addresses the conference later in the day, then meets privately with the governors. On Tuesday, party officials and pollsters appear at the final conference session to discuss what happened in the last elections and what's likely in the next ones.

DOC.HEAD: Hindus, Moslems Fight With Knives, Swords; 14 Killed
DOC.TEXT: Hindus and Moslems fought Sunday with knives and swords in a dispute over a mosque, and police opened fire on rioters, authorities said. At least 14 people were killed. A curfew was imposed on the southern city and policemen were ordered to shoot violators, said police officials, who cannot be named under briefing rules. They said 105 people had been killed since the wave of violence began on Friday in the city of 2 million people. Police opened fire six times during Sunday's street battles, killing at least one person and wounding 10 others, the officials said. They said 28 people were hospitalized with stab wounds. The rioting came as Hindu fundamentalists made new attempts to destroy a 16th century mosque in the remote northern Indian town of Ayodhya, nearly 700 miles from Hyderabad, and replace it with a temple. There also was renewed violence over the issue in the northern town of Aligarh, 250 miles west of Ayodhya, where police said at least 29 people were killed on Friday and Saturday. Hindus first targeted the Mosque of Babar in October. During that month and November, more than 380 people died nationwide in violence related to the dispute. Thousands of Hindus have been congregating in Ayodhya for nearly a week, staging generally peaceful demonstrations near the small mosque, which Hindu fundamentalists claim was built on the ruins of an ancient temple. United News of India said paramilitary troops foiled an attempt to blow up the mosque about midnight Saturday. A 23-year-old Hindu man was arrested when he approached the mosque with three packages of dynamite attached to timed detonators, the news agency said. Murlidhar Reddy, a Hyderabad police commissioner, said at least 30 people were killed on Friday and 60 more died on Saturday. Residents said the trouble started Thursday night when a Hindu crowd stoned the house of Majeed Khan, a leader of the Babri Masjid Action Committee, which is trying to save the Ayodhya mosque. Moslems retaliated by attacking Hindus, and both sides eventually began fighting each other with knives, swords and sticks, the residents said. They also spoke on condition of anonymity. Hindu fundamentalists say the Mosque of Babar was built on the ruins of a temple that they claim was razed by Moslem conquerers. Moslems say the mosque was built on a vacant plot. Archaeologists and historians are divided on the issue. The dispute brought down the government of Prime Minister V.P. Singh last month. Singh lost support when he stopped Hindus from destroying the mosque and said he wanted the issue settled in court. Singh's successor, Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar, has been meeting with Moslem and Hindu leaders in an effort to defuse the problem. Moslems, who make up 12 percent of India's 880 million people, fear the destruction of one mosque would lead to the demolition of many other Islamic shrines and structures across the country. India is officially secular, but the top government ranks are dominated by Hindus, whose make up 82 percent of the population.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Hears Sermon Likening Jackson to Biblical Prophet
DOC.TEXT: President Bush heard a sermon Sunday likening Jesse Jackson to John the Baptist and admonishing people to heed Jackson's calls for racial justice and equality. Bush, who returned Saturday night from his weeklong tour of South America, and his wife Barbara attended a eucharist service at St. John's Episcopal Church across Lafayette Park from the White House. They heard a gospel about John the Baptist, then a brief sermon by the Rev. James C. Holmes urging people to listen to Jackson when he talks about ``the need to turn the racism in our country to justice.'' Jackson, who has twice sought the Democratic presidential nomination, was elected a ``shadow'' senator or lobbyist for the District of Columbia. Holmes said Jackson was criticized in a recent television editorial as having the right message, but being the wrong messenger. That is the way people often react to a prophet, the preacher said. ``The message gets under our skin.'' ``God has always used imperfect messengers,'' he said. ``If we focus on the imperfections, then we block out the message.'' Holmes is assistant pastor of the church, which Bush often attends on the infrequent Sunday mornings he is in Washington. The rector, the Rev. John C. Harper, gave thanks for the release of the hostages in Iraq and Kuwait, and prayed for Bush, the American troops overseas and ``those who pay counsel to the peace of the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Journalist Nears End of Unprecedented Reporting Trip
DOC.TEXT: Like many an affluent tourist on an exotic and expensive jaunt, Toyohiro Akiyama took in the sights, kept his hand-held video camera ever at the ready, and sent off plenty of dispatches to folks back home. But Akiyama made history while he was at it, becoming the first journalist and the first Japanese in space. Akiyama comes back down to Earth Monday, eight days after blasting off into space with two Soviet cosmonauts in a Soyuz space capsule that linked up with the orbiting space station Mir. His employer, the Tokyo Broadcasting System, paid the Soviets $12 million for the round-trip ticket, and spent an additional $25 million on the project. Taking along a paying passenger was an important step in the Soviets' effort to commercialize their space program, and Akiyama's trip has been a relentlessly commercial affair. Japanese corporate sponsors, including a diaper maker and a toothpaste company, displayed them around the launch pad in remote Soviet Central Asia and even plastered them on the rocket itself. TBS, Japan's largest private broadcaster, has made Akiyama the center of its universe throughout the course of the mission, airing nightly prime-time specials and extended weekend coverage of his expoits. Viewers saw the 48-year-old Akiyama get bear hugs from the Soviet cosmonauts when he arrived at the Mir space station on Tuesday, unfurling a banner reading ``The First Japanese in Space.'' Akiyama did not hesitate to share with viewers such details as his space sickness upon experiencing weightlessness. ``I feel things in my stomach are coming out,'' he reported. In a more poetic vein, viewing the Earth from space moved him to recite some Japanese haiku: ``Under the thick cloud there is my country; Approaching, I see my country in a morning sunshine; Behind me is the space in pitch dark; Sad is Africa with no cloud or forest.'' At one point, Akiyama was filmed trying to drink tea from a tube in zero gravity. He was clearly startled when some drops of tea that missed his mouth began floating away. Much of Akiyama's commentary had to do with the pollution on Earth visible from the spacecraft. The skies over Japan and the United States looked dirty and gray, he said. ``I'm not trying to make a big fuss calling for environmental protection, but I honestly think it is beautiful to see where nature is still preserved,'' he said. He also took six Japanese tree frogs into space for experiments on how they adapt to the weightless environment. TBS said videotape of these experiments may be shown later. TBS, which celebrates its 40th anniversary next year, created a special department in 1986 to develop the space project. It sent a staff of 120 camera operators, technicians, correspondents and producers to the Soviet Union to cover the flight. The company expects to lose $7.4 million on the project, even after accounting for advertising revenues and proceeds from documentaries and lectures by Akiyama. TBS had exclusive rights to cover the eight-day flight. The rest of Japan's media prominently covered the blastoff but have since been relatively quiet about the rest of the mission.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslav Republics of Serbia, Montenegro At A Glance
With AM-Yugoslavia-Elections
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures on Serbia, the largest Yugoslav republic, and Montenegro, the smallest. The two are the last Marxist-ruled republics. The first multiparty elections in both republics were held Sunday. Results were not expected until late Monday at the earliest. ---
DOC.HEAD: SERBIA
DOC.TEXT: HISTORY - Constituted at the end of the eighth century. The medieval Serbian state reached its zenith in the mid-14th century under Emperor Dusan, who conquered a large part of Byzantine territory. In 1389 it was occupied by Turkey and remained under its domination until the early 19th century. Re-established as a sovereign state in 1878. Fought Balkan wars in 1912-1913, increasing its territory over present-day Macedonia and Kosovo. Triggered World War I, and after the war it became part of the Kingdom of Serbia, Croatia and Slovenia in 1918. After World War II, became one of the six Yugoslav constituent republics. POPULATION - 9.7 million, of which 6.9 million is eligible to vote. ELECTIONS - First multiparty vote since 1938. Polls opened at 7 a.m. (1 a.m. EST) and closed 12 hours later. Forty-four parties were running for 250 seats for single-chamber parliament, and 32 candidates for the republic's presidency. ---
DOC.HEAD: MONTENEGRO
DOC.TEXT: HISTORY - Formed about the same time as Serbia, but in the course of history was sometimes independent and sometimes under the rule of Serbia. It also fell under the Turkish domination in the 14th century and was re-established as a sovereign kingdom in the 19th century. Following World War I, was taken over by unilateral act of Belgrade government and lost independent status. After World War II, constituted as a Yugoslav republic. POPULATION - 632,647, of which 389,455 are eligible voters. ELECTIONS - First multiparty vote since World War II. Polls opened at 7 a.m. (1 a.m. EST) and closed 12 hours later. Ten parties were running for 125 seats in the single-chamber parliament, three candidates for president and 14 candidates for four seats in the collective presidency.

DOC.HEAD: Serial Killing Trial Stranger Than Fiction
LaserPhoto NY7
DOC.TEXT: The serial murder trial of Arthur J. Shawcross sometimes seems more like an episode of television's ``Twin Peaks'' than a real-life courtroom drama. Throughout the 10-week trial, spectators crowded into the courtroom to hear watch videotaped hypnosis sessions and hear testimony on everything from multiple personalities to cannibalism and the meaning of truth. Among the cast of characters in the Monroe County courtroom drama: a sharp-witted judge, a expert witness who kept wandering off the topic and jurors sporting matching bow ties. The jury is scheduled to begin deliberations Wednesday. Shawcross, 45, is charged with the murders of 10 women over the past two years. The burly, gray-haired defendant made an unlikely centerpiece for the hoopla surrounding him. He sat motionless between his lawyers throughout the trial, staring impassively at the floor. Shawcross confessed in January to the 10 slayings and to an 11th murder in neighboring Wayne County. His lawyers have conceded that he killed the women, but say he was insane when he did it. Jurors watched 12 hours of videotapes in which Shawcross was purportedly under hypnosis. On the tapes, he switched in and out of a high-pitched woman's voice and told defense psychiatrist Dr. Dorothy Lewis that he was once a cannibal in medieval England. The tapes also show Shawcross speaking as his mother, Bessie, his sister, Jeannie, his childhood self and a character he identified as ``Aramus,'' who he said helped him meet girls. In sometimes graphic detail, he described incestuous relations with his sister as a child and wartime atrocities and cannibalism in Vietnam. In the most dramatic portion of the tapes, Shawcross appeared to relive an incident in which he was sexually abused by his mother. He told Lewis his mother's voice told him to kill his victims, and that she ``helped him'' strangle and mutilate one of the women. But in videotaped interviews with prosecution psychiatrist Dr. Park Dietz, Shawcross said he never heard voices or had different personalities. Dietz accused Lewis of creating Shawcross' other personalities by asking leading questions. But Lewis said Shawcross was suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder that arose from severe childhood abuse and brain damage. She said the combination caused Shawcross to lose touch with reality at the time of the slayings. But Dietz testified that Shawcross faked mental illness, modeling himself after the character Norman Bates in the movie ``Psycho.'' He said Shawcross lied about everything from the murders to his claim that he had used rubber baby bottle nipples as gun silencers in Vietnam. The psychiatrist said he tested that claim with a semi-automatic weapon at the Rochester Police Department's gun range. ``It didn't silence anything - the report was equally loud with and without the baby bottle nipple,'' he said with slight smile that was a departure from his normally stern demeanor.
