Dietz's efficient testimony contrasted sharply with the stream-of-consciousness testimony of Lewis. Her answers frequently wandered onto topics like Sigmund Freud's use of hypnotism and the history of psychiatry. Judge Donald Wisner frequently admonished her, saying she would have to restrain herself ``in order to complete this trial before spring.'' Lewis' inability to give simple yes or no answers, as well as her apparent difficulty remembering dates, times and facts, provoked a series of standoffs with prosecutor Charles Siragusa. ``I can't chew gum and walk at the same time,'' Lewis told a chuckling jury as she shuffled through the stack of papers on her lap, trying to find an answer to one of Siragusa's questions. ``Is the extent of your organization indicated by the file on your lap?'' Siragusa asked sarcastically. In another exchange, Lewis and Siragusa had a lengthy philosophical debate over the meaning of truth, as the psychiatrist attempted to distinguish between intentional and unintentional falsehoods. ``Are you saying that fantasy can be the truth?'' an exasperated Siragusa finally asked. ``I'm saying that having a fantasy can be the truth,'' Lewis retorted. ``I'm sure you have them.'' ``And you do as well, is that right?'' Siragusa asked. ``Probably very similar,'' Lewis said. ``I doubt that,'' Siragusa snapped back. ``Can we get back to the case now?'' asked the judge, as the jury and spectators laughed. The jury made its own contribution to the bizarre proceedings - showing up one day in football jerseys and, a week later, in matching bow ties.

DOC.HEAD: Scholars Searching for Clues to Mark Coronado's Trail
DOC.TEXT: Scholars are having trouble putting Francisco Vasquez de Coronado on the map. They want to add the 16th century Spaniard's route through the Southwest to the National Trails System, but they aren't getting much help from the explorer and his party. ``Coronado and his men had no idea where they had gone. They were marching off the end of the known world,'' said Don Blakeslee, Wichita State University anthropology department chairman. Blakeslee and Betty Romero, director of the Rice County Coronado-Quivira Museum in Lyons, are coordinating the project for the Coronado Trail Association. They've been combing historical documents - including letters Coronado wrote the king of Spain and accounts by participants - in hopes of determining which of 30 proposed routes is the right one. ``There are plenty of people who have a pet idea where he went,'' Blakeslee said. ``Every little town anywhere near where he might have gone would like to be able to claim Coronado.'' In 1540, Coronado and his entourage - 300 soldiers and some 1,500 Indian guides and camp followers - set out from Mexico to search for the legendary gold-rich Seven Cities of Cibola. For two years, together and in separate groups, they explored Arizona, New Mexico, Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas. Though they found no gold, they helped open the region to colonization. Romero says she wants her museum to become an interpretative center for the trail. In April, the museum will sponsor a symposium for scholars to view exhibits of armor and weapons used by the conquistadors and debate where Coronado and his men traveled. ``We're going to try to throw out as many wrong ideas as we can in a short period of time,'' Blakeslee said. ``But we haven't yet gotten all of the people together who need to be in one room arguing with one another. And we haven't done all of the field work, which is absolutely critical.'' Blakeslee said the field work could quickly eliminate some routes. One proposed path the anthropology professor checked out was obviously wrong. He said he crossed the Cimarron River where the route's proponent said Coronado crossed. But the canyon the explorers described was not there. Coronado's letters and the other texts offer clues, but few definite directions. ``These records really weren't written to tell anybody how to get to the places mentioned,'' Blakeslee said. Ambiguities in the texts also have frustrated scholars, Blakeslee said. In one passage, the explorers wrote about eating nuts growing in the area they were traveling through, but did not say what kind of nuts. One person assumed the nuts were pecans and based a proposed route on that assumption, Blakeslee said. ``You can't base your arguments on assumptions,'' he said. ``You have to base them on something in the texts. Then you can make an assumption, if there is any way to test it.'' Romero and Blakeslee are hoping new information on Indian trails may play a big role in assembling the jigsaw puzzle that previously had critical pieces missing. Coronado had Indian guides who apparently knew the country because they were able to lead the hundreds of soldiers to good water every night of their travels in August in southwestern Kansas, Blakeslee said. By using historical accounts, old maps, letters and other documents, Blakeslee has established locations for many Indian trails in the Great Plains. Just about everything important in the early history of the Plains happened along established trails, he said. Most of the eight trails already in the system, including the Santa Fe Trail in Kansas, were established along precisely known routes, Blakeslee said. Some trails are still marked by wagon ruts or other physical features. But delineating Coronado's trail hasn't been so simple. The National Park Service was unprepared for the task when ordered by Congress to study the feasibility of establishing a Coronado trail, Blakeslee said. ``It takes a lot more effort, more manpower and entirely different techniques,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov Wins 18th Game, Moves into Lead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with description of play, last moves Sunday, next game scheduled for Monday. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Garry Kasparov on Sunday won the 18th game in the world chess championship, moving into the lead as rival Anatoly Karpov abandoned the game in the second day of play. The victory gave Kasparov, the defending champion, 9.5 points against Karov's 8.5 points with a maximum six games left to play. The first player to gain 12.5 points wins the championship and $1.7 million of a $3 million purse. In the event of a tie, Kasparov retains his title. Experts said that Kasparov, playing white, held the advantage when the game was adjourned Saturday night after the maximum five hours of play. He made 17 more moves Sunday to win. Karpov, weakened with the loss of a pawn he had sacrificed the day before, resigned in the 57th move. Kasparov's victory marked the third time since the start of the series Oct. 8 in New York that he has moved ahead of his rival, who also has held the world championship title. He had won the second and 16th games, but Karpov evened the past leads out with wins in the seventh and 17th games. All the other games have been draws. As in the second game, Kasparov surprised his rival with a stronger opening Saturday. Karpov was hard-pressed to compensate for the deficit he suffered in sacrificing a pawn. On Sunday, Kasparov had no trouble exploiting his advantage. The 19th game was scheduled for Monday afternoon. The first 12 games in the series were played in New York. The 13th game started in Lyon on Nov. 24.

DOC.HEAD: Exhibit Recounts Jewish Contributions to Florida History
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Some Florida Jews suffer a stereotype as ``cranky Yankees'' who head south for the low taxes and cheap condos, and have little regard for their cultural heritage. Professor Henry Green, head of Judaic studies at the University of Miami, hopes to change all that. ``When you think of Florida and Jews you basically think of condo commandos searching for early-bird specials,'' Green said. ``But the Jews have been here since the beginning, contributing since the beginning.'' The history of Florida Jews has been compiled into an exhibit entitled ``Mosaic, Jewish Life in Florida.'' It is on display at Miami's Historical Museum of Southern Florida through Jan. 6. Then it will travel the state for two years and head to Israel in 1993. About 90 percent of Florida's 750,000 Jews live in the three South Florida counties of Palm Beach, Broward and Dade, making it the region with the third largest population of Jews in the world, after Israel and the New York area. The exhibit began as a grass-roots project for a Jewish community center in Plantation, a sleepy suburban city west of Fort Lauderdale, and blossomed into a collection of thousands of Jewish artifacts, documents, photographs and oral histories donated by people from two dozen Jewish communities around the state. It has become an official project of the Christopher Columbus Quincentenary in two years, which marks the 500th anniversary of the Italian explorer's arrival in the Western Hemisphere. Green, director of Mosaic, believes at least five crew members on Columbus' first voyage were ``conversos,'' Jews who converted to Christianity in an attempt to save their lives during the Spanish Inquisition. ``We have survived for so long, but you can't perpetuate unless you know your own history,'' said Beverly Kaiman of Pensacola, where the state's first Sephardic Jews settled in 1763. Her relatives first came to Pensacola, located in the Florida panhandle, from Russia at the turn of the century. The family donated a Russian teapot, a ``yahzheit,'' which is a record of debts owed by relatives, and several photographs to the exhibit. Jean Leibert has lived in Miami since 1956. She said the exhibit showed her ties to the state she didn't know she had. ``It's given me more of a strong feeling of being a part of Florida, like I have roots here,'' she said. Leibert said she was surprised to learn that Levy County was named after one of the first Jewish families in Florida. Moses Levy, fleeing anti-Semitism in Morocco, landed in Central Florida in 1819 and bought 52,000 acres of land near Gainesville. A strict Zionist, he intended to create a ``New Jerusalem.'' That plan failed when few Jews answered his ads in European newspapers. Levy's son, David Levy Yulee, who helped draft Florida's constitution, was the first Jewish U.S. senator. Other little-known facts Mosaic's researchers discovered: - Jewish women in the 19th century made their dishes kosher by washing them with sand and sea water in Pensacola and Miami Beach. - In the 1950s, the Jewish owners of the South Beach Blackstone Hotel on Miami Beach invited black Baptist ministers to be their guests when the ministers could find no other accommodations in racially segregated Miami. - Key West Jews in the 1890s formed the Committee to Aid the Cubans, supporting the revolution against Spain. In gratitude, revolutionary leader Jose Marti paid a courtesy visit to committee chairman Louis Fine. Also part of Mosaic is a U.S. Army-supplied knapsack with candles and a kiddush cup for ritual prayer. The items were used during World War II by Rabbi Sidney Lefkowitz of Jacksonville, the military chaplain who performed the first Jewish service in Germany after the Holocaust. One old photograph in the exhibit is of Marcus Joseph Weinkle, a Russian Jew who was called to serve in the Russian army in 1887. Just before he was to leave, his family the announced he had suddenly died. After he was buried, he crawled out of his grave and took clothes and money that had been hidden for him and smuggled himself out of the country through Turkey. Weinkle eventually moved to Moffit, Fla., where he opened a lumber mill. Stephen Whitfield, a professor of American studies at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., said the exhibit was important because South Florida was the best hope for the future of the Jewish South. ``It's the only spot in the South where Jewish life will be vibrant, so the caliber and character of that community is crucial,'' he said. The exhibit also could help improve ethnic relations in South Florida, said Joseph Mensch, a trustee of the historical museum. ``Miami is a multiethnic society that must learn to get along with each other,'' Mensch said. ``This adds to the melting pot that helps us live together.''

DOC.HEAD: National Weather Service Opens Meteorology Museum
DOC.TEXT: For people who think weather forecasts are worthy of more than idle elevator chatter, the National Weather Service had opened a museum dedicated to the long and proud history of meteorology, curators say. The National Weather Service Science and History Center opened last month in suburban Washington. ``Weather is always a fascinating subject because we are helpless in nature. We are in awe of its turbulent state,'' said Bill Stanley, a federal historian who designed the museum. The museum, located in the new offices of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, occupies only 1,100 square feet, has no staff and is open only on weekdays. A wall near the entrance displays photographs of cars bobbing down a flooded street, lightning in a turbulent sky and a funnel cloud descending on a field. A dripping sound comes from simulated rain in the window of a model 1891 weather office and a voice drones on with the latest data from the national Weather Radio. Television monitors near the entrance show the weather all over the country. The museum also chronicles names and dates in weather recording, which dates back at least 200 years in the United States, Stanley said. Originally intended to help farmers, weather forecasting became popular in 1870 through the Army Signal Corps and the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Thomas Jefferson is said to have requested a break while working on the Declaration of Independence on July 3, 1776, to take his thermometer outside and check the temperature. Since 1940, the weather service has operated under the U.S. Department of Commerce and the oceanic and atmospheric agency. The museum's displays show how the science of meteorology has progressed from simple weather vanes, barometers, rain gauges and record books to high-tech devices like geostationary operational environmental satellite imagers, Stanley said. David Ruth, a meteorologist under contract with the National Weather Service visited the museum recently. He said it was good to finally see a memorial to his profession. ``Well,'' he said. ``It's certainly a lot nicer than what we had before.''

DOC.HEAD: Saddam's Armies Seen As Long-Term Threat Even With Withdrawal
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Some diplomats and other observers can see the rough outlines of a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis emerging. But any face-saving formula that induces Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait leaves a long-term question: what to do about his large and powerful military. ``We can't accept being next to a country ready to invade any morning,'' said a senior Saudi diplomat, who like his colleagues spoke on condition of anonymity. A Saudi source knowledgeable on military affairs said Sunday that the release of hostages by Saddam may signal a planned withdrawal from Kuwait, and that chances of peace are better than those of war. So far, Saddam has shown no inclination to pull his 460,000 troops from the Kuwait theater and reinstate the Kuwaiti ruling family, two key U.N. demands. But he has agreed to release foreign hostages, which the Security Council has repeatedly called on him to do. The first group of them flew out on Sunday. The United States is pouring troops into Saudi Arabia, and expects to have a force of more than 400,000 ready for offensive action by Jan. 15. That is the deadline the United Nations Security Council set for an Iraqi withdrawal, authorizing ``all necessary means'' to get him out after that. On the heels of the resolution, Saddam accepted President Bush's offer to send Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Baghdad, and agreed to send Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to come to Washington. Then, on Friday, the Iraqi Parliament approved Saddam's call to release all foreign hostages. Washington, for its part, announced it would withdraw all its diplomats from the embassy in Kuwait, but not officially close the mission. Iraq had ordered all missions in Kuwait shut, declaring the country its 19th province. Both sides, then, can save face by pointing to diplomatic gains while downplaying what they conceded. ``You leave something vague and one party presents it as a gain on their behalf and the other party can too,'' said a Middle Eastern diplomat. On Sunday, Britain's Observer newspaper reported that Iraq has redrawn its border with Kuwait in what could signal plans to withdraw as early as next month, a newspaper reported Sunday. The report said Iraq was laying claim to an area of the Rumailah oilfield and the islands of Warba and Bubiyan in the Persian Gulf, which it has long coveted. Saudi officials denied the report. But one Saudi diplomat said Persian Gulf leaders might be willing to pay Saddam money to assuage him. He claims that Kuwait stole billions of dollars in oil revenues from Iraq. In any event, an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait is seen as only the first step in stripping Saddam of his military capabilities. ``If you don't get rid of him now, you'll have to do it two years from now, or three years from now, or five years from now. And you'll have to pay a much higher price,'' said the Saudi source. Saddam has threatened to use his chemical arsenal and some observers believe he could develop a nuclear bomb during this decade. With that firepower, he could dictate his neighbors' actions without necessarily moving troops. But it would be difficult to send U.S. soldiers into action now on the basis of a possible future war. ``Is it worth American lives to prevent a hypothetical situation?'' said a Western diplomat. Some Saudi officials also are reluctant to push for the total destruction of Iraq, worried about who might emerge in Saddam's place. The immediate need, diplomats believe, is to concentrate on winning a withdrawal from Kuwait without an all-out fight. ``If to want to get Saddam out of Kuwait without a war, make it clear to him that you will kill him on Jan. 15,'' said the Saudi source. Then the alliance could look for a formula to contain Saddam. That might involve Iraqi guarantees of no more aggression, some economic and military sanctions on Baghdad and a multinational presence in the region for up to four years while Saudi Arabia builds a military. ``It's like cutting the leaves of a plant that climbed over the wall,'' said the Middle Eastern diplomat. ``The root is still there. You have to cut the tree or at least the branches.'' ---
EDITOR'S NOTE: Neil MacFarquhar, now on assignment in Saudi Arabia, covers Arab affairs for The Associated Press in Nicosia, Cyprus.

DOC.HEAD: Carter Cautions Bush To Be Flexible in Persian Gulf Talks
DOC.TEXT: Former President Jimmy Carter says U.S. officials should be flexible and not simply issue ultimatums in upcoming talks with Iraqi leaders so as to avoid the likelihood of war in the Persian Gulf. ``If the exchanges are to be genuine, it will be necessary not to lay down patently unacceptable preconditions or unalterable demands,'' Carter said in an essay to be published in the Dec. 17 issue of Newsweek magazine. ``Meetings just to deliver an ultimatum,'' warns Carter, ``will not be productive; they will likely lead to war.'' ``We must have some flexibility,'' he said. U.S. and Iraqi officials are currently considering when to schedule face-to-face talks between President Bush and Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in Washington and Secretary of State James A. Baker III and President Saddam Hussein in Baghdad. The United Nations has authorized the use of force against Saddam if his troops aren't out of Kuwait by Jan. 15. Carter warned that ``some of the goals of both sides have to be considered'' in any talks to obtain a peaceful resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis. Saddam must withdraw Iraqi forces from Kuwait and return the Kuwaiti regime to power, as stipulated by the United Nations, said Carter. He noted that Saddam already has agreed to one of the three basic U.N. demands - the release of foreign hostages. But the United States and its allies must also make some concessions, Carter said. There may need to be what Carter called ``an independent settlement of differences,'' possibly an international conference to address the Israeli-Palestinian question. Carter acknowledges, however, that ``strong political reasons'' make it impractical for such a conference to be linked with the Kuwait issue. Israel opposes such a conference. Additionally, Carter suggested the allies might forgive Iraq's debt and offer a long-term land lease that would give the nation access to the Persian Gulf. On the question of war, Carter said President Bush will be forced to ``convince'' the American public that Kuwait's liberation will ``justify the casualties of a major war.'' And he said most of the major Arab allies would not join in an attack on Iraq, making the military action an ``American operation.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Bruce Willis says he thinks about suing the supermarket tabloids every day. ``What more could they do to me?'' he asks in an interview in the January 1991 of Vanity Fair. Willis says tabloids have printed things he said in jest as fact and made up stories, like one about him saving an actress on a runaway horse. ``In that movie, there were no horses,'' Willis said. ``People say, `Why do you care? It makes you look so good.' But if they can print that lie, they can just as easily print that I had sex with a goat. A lie is a lie.'' Given his feelings about tabloid reporters, Willis was asked why he agreed to play a tabloid reporter in his newest film, ``The Bonfire of the Vanities'' -a chacter who is a ruthless, boozy scavenger of stories. ``That's why,'' he replied. --- BOSTON (AP) - Massachusetts Gov. Michael S. Dukakis wishes people would miss him when he leaves office next month. ``I wish I were going out with people feeling somewhat better about Mike Dukakis than they do right now,'' the former presidential candidate said in an interview televised Sunday. He went on to say that ``despite the difficulty of the past two years, this is a lot nicer going out voluntarily than being thrown out, as happened to me in 1978.'' That year, Dukakis, the incumbent governor, lost a primary battle to retain his seat. He later regained the governor's office, but after losing the presidency in 1988 to George Bush, the state's economy ebbed and his popularity at home plummeted. ``I got close to the top of the mountain, unfortunately, failed,'' he said. ``It's been an extraordinary time and life for me.'' --- LONDON (AP) - Former President Reagan ended a five-day visit to Britain over the weekend that included tea with former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Reagan, 79, left London's Heathrow Airport on Saturday with his wife, Nancy, aboard a private jet. During his stay, Reagan renewed his personal ``special relationship'' with Mrs. Thatcher over tea and cakes at his London hotel, and visited her successor, John Major, at No. 10 Downing St. The Reagans also had lunch with the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh at Buckingham Palace. And Reagan addressed the Cambridge University debating society on its 175th anniversary. --- SAN ANTONIO (AP) - Michigan Gov.-elect John Engler married Texas attorney Michelle DeMunbrun in a ceremony attended by about 45 friends and relatives. Saturday's marriage is the second for both Engler and his wife. ``It was very beautiful,'' said Engler as the two emerged from St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church. ``I'm very, very happy,'' he added later. Engler, 42, and Ms. DeMunbrun, 32, met earlier this year through one of Engler's staff members and became engaged in August, but they kept their wedding plans secret until the day after Engler narrowly defeated incumbent Democrat Gov. James Blanchard on Nov. 6. ``We didn't want this to become part of the campaign, part of the commentary of politics, so we didn't tell anybody,'' Engler said. Only a few family members and partners in Ms. DeMunbrun's Houston law firm of Nathan, Wood and Sommers were told. Most of the guests were members of the bride's family. Engler has said the couple will spend time with his relatives next week in Michigan. They plan to honeymoon in the spring. --- APPLETON, Wis. (AP) - A little help from local law enforcement was all the Hager Twins of ``Hee Haw'' fame needed to create a traffic jam. The look-alike singers known for their years on the long-running program visited northeastern Wisconsin work on a music video for a tune called ``I'm Wishin' I Could Go Fishin' Forever.'' The video, with a classic country theme, starts with Jim and John Hager in hard hats and work clothes in a pickup truck, stuck in a traffic jam in Ashland, where traffic jams are uncommon. ``We called up the police chief and told him what we were doing, and that we needed a traffic jam,'' Jim said. ``He said, `What time?' When we got there, he had the main street blocked off and cars lined up for the traffic jam. It was wonderful.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands March For Human Rights, Remember Sakharov
LaserPhoto MOSB1,MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: Religious chants echoed off the walls of KGB headquarters Sunday as thousands of human rights demonstrators prayed and wept at a nearby monument to the victims of Soviet repression. Led by three Russian Orthodox priests bearing icons, marchers carried wreaths, placards denouncing President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and photographs of human rights activist Andrei Sakharov, who died one year ago this week. The 3,000 to 4,000 protesters came from near Red Square where they had rallied to mark Monday's International Human Rights Day. They shouted repeatedly for Gorbachev to resign and heard radical politicians deride him as ``His Majesty, Mikhail the Bloody.'' The five-hour demonstration reached a more somber climax across the street from the Lubyanka, the secret police headquarters and former prison, where a monument has been erected to the millions of innocents who perished under Communist rule. More than 10 million people are believed to have been shot or died from hunger, cold or hard labor in labor camps under previous Soviet leaders. ``Lord, take the souls of these innocent victims under your protection,'' a small choir chanted as a priest clad in gold robes and carrying incense walked around the monument. Their requiem, amplified through megaphones, reverberated off the pink, gray and yellow granite facade of the KGB building. The 8-foot-long and 3-foot-wide rock monument, hewn from the Solovetsky Islands in the White Sea, the site of a famous labor camp, was dedicated in October. Lighted candles flickered in the hands of participants, who stood stoically around the flower-strewn stone in 23-degree temperatures as dusk fell. Organizers released dozens of doves, which circled Dzerzhinsky Square. The Rev. Alexei Vlasov, whose branch of the Russian Orthodox Church was formerly forced to operate underground, told the crowd of Josef Stalin's repression of the clergy. He said the KGB harassed believers and ``the church ceased to become a sacred place or refuge for people where they could confess their sins.'' As he spoke, tears rolled down the cheeks of Lydia Terekhov. Wax from her candle dripped onto a sign held against her chest. The sign, with a photograph of her 19-year-old son, Igor, said the young KGB border guard was killed in Armenia in April. Mrs. Terekhov is one of dozens of mothers who have become fixtures at several anti-government demonstrations in Moscow this year, protesting the deaths of their sons and demanding the government explain how they died. Other marchers mourned the loss of Sakharov, the Nobel Peace Prize laureate and father of the Soviet Union's human rights movement, who died on Dec. 14, 1989. ``Nobody can possibly replace Sakharov,'' said Lyudmilla Kocheyeva when asked whether any current political figure can take up the late nuclear physicist's role as the nation's conscience. ``He has very many supporters and many who follow his path,'' she said, waiting to place her candle on the memorial stone. Organizers of the rally sent a delegation of lawmakers to place a wreath on Sakharov's grave in a southwest Moscow cemetery. During earlier speeches to the demonstrators near Red Square, radicals accused Gorbachev of trampling on the human rights of the country's many diverse ethnic groups. Nikolai Ivanov, who was fired as government prosecutor while trying to expose corruption, said Gorbachev was a ``czar'' who came to power by being chosen by 15-20 ``senile Politburo members.'' ``Today, we can call him `His Majesty, Mikhail the Bloody,' because for decades, the country hasn't experienced such bloodshed,'' Ivanov said. ``Who bore responsibility for pogroms in Sumgait, Fergana, Baku, Osh and many other places?'' Ivanov asked, referring to the sites of recent ethnic violence. ``It's Gorbachev himself who is leading the country to civil war. ``Therefore, if we want to defend human rights, we must unite around such democratic forces as the Russian parliament, headed by Boris Nikolayevich Yeltsin,'' he said, referring to the president of Russia, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics.

DOC.HEAD: Toy Store Removes Tramp Doll After Protest by Homeless
DOC.TEXT: A national toy-store chain has stopped selling ``Steve the Tramp'' dolls after some people and others picketed outside a mall and complained that the character from Dick Tracy demeans the homeless. The doll, sold by the Walt Disney Co., is described on its packages as an ``ignorant bum ... dirty and scarred from a life on the streets. You'll smell him before you see him.'' A protest Friday by 12 people at the Stamford Town Center persuaded Kay Bee Toy & Hobby to remove the doll from its 1,200 stores, said Ken Cunniff, vice president of advertising for the California-based chain. ``The character would be fine if it was just an old curmudgeon, but I think the copy on the package goes too far,'' Cunniff said. Homeless people and activists in Stamford organized a protest against the doll after an Episcopal priest, the Rev. Christopher Rose of Hartford, put the doll at the top of his annual list of ``Warped Toys for Christmas,'' which he circulates to social action groups. ``I'm homeless, and you don't smell me before you see me,'' said Carlton Whitehorn, one of the protesters on Friday. ``I'd like to let Disney know that Jesus Christ was homeless, too.'' The doll is one of 14 figures of criminals and mobsters inspired by the movie ``Dick Tracy,'' which was produced by Disney's Touchstone Pictures. The package containing the doll reads: ``Hardened and bitter after a life on the mean streets, Steve the Tramp is a lout who would just as soon take your life as your wallet. Despite a low I.Q., he's as dangerous as they come because he doesn't have anything to lose.'' In a statement Friday, the Walt Disney Co. defended the toy as ``not intended in any way to represent the homeless.''

DOC.HEAD: Freed Americans Tell of Fear, Frustration in Occupied Kuwait
With AM-Gulf-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some of the Americans freed by the Baghdad government on Sunday had spent four months hiding from Iraqi occupation authorities in Kuwait, living by their wits and by the kindness of Kuwaiti friends. Thomas Kreuzman, 38, of Holiday, Fla., who was a contractor in Kuwait before the Aug. 2 invasion, said he spent 23 days hiding in an air-conditioning duct with his dog. They lived on dry spaghetti and sneaked out at night for water, he said. About 80 Americans flew from Kuwait to Baghdad Sunday, later joining a group of about 175 Americans who left the Iraqi capital for Frankfurt, Germany. They spoke to reporters at the Baghdad airport. Lyonell Hoffman, 51, of Melbourne, Fla., who was also contractor in Kuwait, said he hid out in an apartment complex. ``I am stunned and still cannot believe it, it seems like a miracle,'' he said of his release. The departing Americans described the systematic looting of the small, wealthy emirate that had been their home. ``It was not an invasion, it was robbery,'' said Kreuzman. ``All that wasn't tied down was taken away.'' The Iraqi occupation authorities threatened Kuwaitis who sheltered foreigners with death. But the Americans said Kuwaitis repeatedly risked their lives to help them. ``I feel guilty for leaving my Kuwaiti friends behind,'' said Kreuzman. Several of the Americans said they had heard gunfire in the city every night since the invasion - including their last night there, Saturday. Some of the hostages who were detained in Iraq celebrated their last night in the country with a party at the downtown Al-Mansour Melia, which was known as the ``hostage hotel'' because many were held there. One American who was held in Iraq said now that he was free, he wanted to go to Kuwait, not to the United States. Dr. Clem J. Hall of Newark, N.J., said he wanted to go back to the emirate for his Yugoslav girlfriend. Thousands of Westerners were stranded by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein refused to let them leave. In recent months, Saddam had freed hostages on a piecemeal basis, sometimes in large groups, and sometimes after a foreign dignitary made an appeal on their behalf. On Thursday, he announced he was ready to free all foreigners, and the decree was approved by the Iraqi parliament on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Two Yugoslav Republics Hold Key Elections; Vote-Rigging Alleged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with boycott by ethnic Albanians, further claims by Draskovic; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Poland-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Opposition candidates accused the government of cheating Sunday as the two Communist-ruled republics held elections that could decide whether Yugoslavia remains united. In Serbia, the country's largest republic, the top nationalist party said it might not accept the election results. The Serbian Renewal Movement accused the ruling Socialists of permitting illegal voting, and most ethnic Albanians boycotted the election. The Socialists - formerly Communists - faced an array of center-right nationalists in Serbia's first free elections in more than 50 years. In Montenegro, the smallest republic, 10 parties were challenging the ruling Marxists. Polling stations in both republics opened at 7 a.m. (1 a.m. EST) and were closing 12 hours later. Results were expected late Monday at the earliest. The outcome in Serbia could shape the entire country's future. The nationalist Serbian Renewal Movement, led by novelist Vuk Draskovic, wants to establish free-market capitalism and return the republic to its once-dominant role in the Yugoslav federation. The western states of Croatia and Slovenia, where center-right parties replaced Communists in spring elections, want more independence from the federation and have threatened to secede. Serbia's current Socialist leader, Slobodan Milosevic, has refused to discuss the possibility of secession with Slovenia and Croatia. Draskovic, his opponent, says he wants to keep the country whole but is prepared to negotiate with other republics that favor separation or confederation. Observers say the tensions between Serbia and the Slovenes and Croats could increase if Milosevic is kept in power, while a Draskovic presidency could reduce tensions. In Montenegro, the ruling Marxists also oppose independence for Slovenia and Croatia. The conflict is only one of many based on ethnic and political differences among Yugoslavia's six constituent states and two provinces. The CIA has predicted that the country could break up within 18 months and has warned of the possibility of civil war. Serbian voters were also choosing a 250-member parliament from among 44 vying parties. Draskovic accused the government of allowing some voters to cast their ballots on Saturday. He said his party protested the alleged illegality to the electoral commission, but the complaint was rejected. He also claimed envelopes containing mailed-in votes from soldiers were not sealed and could be tampered with. ``If we ascertain that the vote-rigging on Saturday was massive, we will not recognize the elections,'' Draskovic said. ``Communists don't know a thing about honesty. They are capable of doing anything to stay in power.'' Socialist officials said only a small number of people, mainly disabled persons and those who had proof they had to be away on business Sunday, were allowed to vote on Saturday. Opposition leaders also claimed the Socialists stopped registering deaths in Serbia in April, and planned to rig the election by claiming phantom votes. Pre-election polls gave Communists a slight lead over Draskovic's party. But they also showed that nearly 40 percent of the 6,865,445 eligible voters were undecided. Runoff elections in districts where the leader fails to get at least 50 percent of the votes are slated for Dec. 23. In Kosovo, a semi-autonomous region of Serbia, ethnic Albanians said they were boycotting the voting to protest direct Serbian rule that was imposed over the summer when Kosovo's parliament declared the region's sovereignty. People of Albanian origins make up 90 percent of Kosovo's population of two million. ``We have asked our people to stay at home,'' said Ibrahim Rugova, leader of the Democratic League of Kosovo, which is not recognized by Serbian authorities and is not fielding candidates Sunday. ``Serbian police control continues ... if we accept the elections, we accept the suspension of autonomy,'' he said. In the Kosovo town of Glogovac, only 13 of 25,000 registered voters turned out and they were all Serbs, the state news agency Tanjug reported. Ethnic Albanians account for about 750,000 of the province's estimated 950,000 eligible voters. ``There were hardly any Albanians on the streets today,'' said Jusuf Buxhovi, an official of the Democratic League. In the earlier crackdown, authorities closed the Kosovo assembly and forced Albanian-language media to stop publishing. Rugova said thousands of ethnic Albanians were sacked from state jobs. Serbia's new constitution allows its leaders to decide whether Kosovo and the republic's second autonomous region, Vojvodina, should have self-rule.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Soldier Killed When Bombs Explode
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 20 grafs for 4-18 bgng `Two homemade...' to ADD details of bombing; statement warning of more violence; CORRECTS death toll to ADD soldier's death Sunday; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JRL1
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli soldier was killed and two were wounded when bombs exploded outside military headquarters in the occupied town of Bethlehem on Sunday, the third anniversary of the Palestinian uprising. In other violence, an Arab was fatally shot as he tried to strangle an Israeli policeman and grab his rifle Sunday, the army said. Relatives said he was shot while standing at the door of his home. Soldiers also clashed with masked youths in the West Bank village of Bani Naim, shooting one protester in the leg, the army said. Two homemade bombs went off in the West Bank town of Bethlehem early Sunday evening as an army patrol passed the gate of the military base along the Jerusalem-Bethlehem highway, the army said. Troops clamped a curfew on Bethlehem and surrounding villages, erected roadblocks, and searched for suspects in the area, the army said. Israel army radio said six paratroopers were walking along the highway in a routine patrol when the first bomb exploded. The patrol checked out the explosion, found nothing and continued walking, the report said. After the soldiers had walked another 30 yards, the second bomb went off, wounding three soldiers. One of the soldiers suffered critical head injuries and died in the emergency room of Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem, said hospital spokeswoman Ruth Mekel. The two other soldiers were slightly hurt. The death brought to 10 the number of Israeli soldiers killed during the uprising, the army said. Curfews confined more than a million Arabs to their homes in the occupied territories, some for the third straight day, in an army effort to quell violence on the anniversary of the intefadeh, or uprising. ``At the moment, we have beefed up forces, and increased patrols, lookouts and roadblocks,'' said a lieutenant enforcing the curfew on the Dheisheh refugee camp in the occupied West Bank. Soldiers fired at stone-throwers breaking the curfew in the Gaza Strip village of Beni Suhaila, wounding 25-year-old Muhamad Mardi al-Madani in the right thigh, Arab reports said. Relatives said Al-Madani was hit as he stood at the door of his house. Hospital officials said the bullet severed Al-Madani's artery and he bled to death. The army also confirmed he had died. But the army said he attacked a member of the paramilitary border police, trying to strangle the officer and take his rifle. It said the Israeli was slightly injured in the melee by a ricocheting bullet. Sunday's violence brought to 777 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis during the uprising and to 54 the number of Israelis who have died in the violence. Another 316 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of helping Israel, since the uprising began Dec. 9, 1987. The army curfews coincided with a general strike called by uprising leaders to mark the anniversary. Virtually all shops and schools and traffic were idle. Slogans on walls near Manger Square in nearby Bethlehem called for 1991 to be ``the year of destroying the enemy.'' They were signed by the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a Marxist faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Another slogan signed by the fundamentalist group Islamic Jihad said: ``The language of stones, knives, and bullets is the only language the enemy will understand.'' Army radio reported that only Jewish settlers and army patrols were seen driving in the occupied territories. Large sections of the West Bank, including such principal cities as Nablus and Hebron, as well as virtually all of the Gaza Strip, were under curfew for the third straight day. Masked activists in the Dheisheh refugee camp defied the curfew Saturday night and marched through the alleys carrying Palestinian flags, Arab reports said. Two jailed Palestinian leaders and a left-wing Israeli legislator issued a joint statement Sunday saying violence on both sides will increase if the peace process remains deadlocked. ``We are deeply concerned that if negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians will not start soon, both peoples will find themselves in a very tragic situation of deterioration manifested by terror and oppression,'' said the statement. The statement was issued by Yossi Sarid of the Citizens Rights Movement and Palestinian journalists Radwan Abu Ayyash and Ziad Abu Ziad. The two Palestinians have been jailed by Israel for six months without trial.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Returns to Power One Day After Resignation
DOC.TEXT: Chatichai Choonhavan was renamed prime minister Sunday, one day after he resigned amid increasing criticism of his government. The maneuver Saturday was apparently an attempt to revamp his Cabinet. King Bhumibol Adulyadej signed a royal decree reinstating Chatichai as prime minister, Channel 7 television reported. Chatichai, 68, a former army general, told reporters Sunday that he had not been pressured by the military into resigning. He said he has been in close contact with military leaders. All the Cabinet ministers automatically lost their positions with the prime minister's resignation Saturday. Chatichai now will choose a new Cabinet, but it remained to be seen whether he would drop members who had been sharply criticized by the powerful military. There have been increasing attacks on Chatichai's squabbling seven-party coalition for corruption, ineptitude and internal squabbling. The former Cabinet is continuing to serve in a caretaker capacity. Chatichai, who came to power in August 1988, is the first prime minister since 1976 to be an elected member of the Parliament. The generally popular prime minister has proved a skillful political player, especially in neutralizing the military, which for decades intervened by force. But the military has also insisted on being a ``watchdog'' over state and society. Criticism mounted in recent months, with critics pointing to allegedly massive corruption within the highest levels of his government and parties within the coalition. Some have also complained of the government's poor record of helping the country's poor while allowing entrepreneurs free rein. Recently pamphlets have circulated that accuse Chatichai and his family of corrupt dealings and nepotism. Army Chief Gen. Suchinda Kapayoon, armed forces chief Gen. Sunthorn Kongsompong and others have made tough statements and threats in recent months. Their focus has been on corruption and certain Cabinet members including Interior Minister Banharn Silapa-Archa, Communications Minister Montri Pongpanich and Deputy Minister of Education Chalerm Yumbamrung. anharn is secretary-general of Chatichai's own Chart Thai Party, and Montri holds the same post with the Social Action Party. The outspoken Chalerm had angered the military by criticizing its seizure in June of a government-owned radio truck that officers said was eavesdropping on military communications. There was a major Cabinet shuffle on Aug. 27, but military commanders demanded even more changes and threatened unspecified intervention if Chalerm and others were not ousted. Another change came Nov. 22, but proved minor. Chalerm, who had been a minister in the prime minister's office, was merely demoted to the education ministry slot.

DOC.HEAD: From Peasant Hut to President's Palace
With AM-Poland-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Lech Walesa. Looking at the peasant's son, seeing the hut in the potato field where he was born, recalling Poland's last four decades of communism, the title would not seem possible. But then, this is Lech Walesa. Love him or fear him, he epitomizes the contradictory forces that led Poland out of communism and forever changed the East-West equation. He has uncanny political intuition and personal courage, and he wants to take the future of his country into his hands. He is devoutly Catholic and disinterested in the trappings of power or prestige. With workers and rulers alike, he woos with his greatest asset: He is always himself. That includes saying one thing in the morning and another at night, and then warning others not to pay too much attention to either ``Walesa.'' He frequently refers to himself in the third person. His charisma edges toward egotism, his self-confidence toward the autocratic. As fervently as he has fought for democracy, he believes he ``must reserve my own voice as the final one.'' That voice comes from a mud-and-marsh hamlet northwest of Warsaw where in 1943, as World War II raged across the Polish flatlands, Walesa was born in a tiny three-room hut. The road leading to it is unpaved to this day. Walesa's father died in 1945, his health ruined by forced labor under the German occupiers, and his mother married her late husband's brother a year later. With too little land to survive, the impoverished clan rented out the boys to work for other farmers and sent young Lech to learn tractor repair at a local trade school. It was not until 1967 that the 24-year-old Walesa, out of the army and depressed by a broken love affair, sensed time was wasting. He left home for Gdansk. Working at the Lenin Shipyard, a showpiece of People's Poland, Walesa's life was changed in 1970 by Christmas food strikes during which dozens of laborers were killed by security forces. Already angry about poor working conditions, he was chosen to lead the shipyard strike committee. Walesa was dismissed in 1976 for criticizing the yard's Communist union, and he began organizing underground free unions. In August 1980, he made his famous jump over the shipyard fence to lead the strike that gave birth to the East bloc's first free trade union. Martial law ended Solidarity's rocky 15-month existence, and Walesa was imprisoned until November 1982. He received the Nobel Peace Prize the following year but because he was afraid to leave the country, it was accepted by his wife, Danuta. Walesa vowed that Solidarity would survive underground, and after strikes in 1988 the union re-emerged as Poland's main political force. Walesa forced the Communist Party to the negotiating table and, finally, to the dismay of skeptical allies, to give up power. He picked Tadeusz Mazowiecki as the East bloc's first non-Communist government leader and then watche from Gdansk as revolution swept Eastern Europe. Last spring, Walesa started to agitate again, this time to remove a nagging vestige of the old regime - President Wojciech Jaruzelski - and speed up reforms to stave off popular unrest. At first his allies in the government shook their heads, but soon it was evident that, again, Walesa was onto something. They began talking about ``acceleration'' too. Within months, Jaruzelski announced an early end to his term, and the first fully democratic nationwide elections in five decades were scheduled to pick a new occupant for Belweder Palace. But Mazowiecki, regarding Walesa's campaign as a rejection of his own cautious-but-determined path, refused to bow to his political sponsor and decided to oppose him for president. Their bitter falling out created a split in Solidarity that is bound to linger after the election. Walesa seems sorry, but ready to move on. ``I am playing as a chess player, five or six moves ahead,'' he said recently.

DOC.HEAD: Independent Lithuanian Communist Party Adopts New Name
DOC.TEXT: The Independent Communist Party of Lithuania, which broke ranks with the Kremlin last year, has renamed itself the Democratic Labor Party, the official Tass news agency reported Sunday. The party was formed in December 1989 after a split in the 200,000-member Lithuanian Communist Party, with one side remaining loyal to Moscow and the other reorganizing along social democratic lines. The new Democratic Labor Party has 56,000 members, the official Soviet news agency said. A weekend convention of 550 delegates in the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius voted to drop the word ``Communist'' and adopt the new name, Tass said. Party leader Algirdas Brazauskas, who is also Lithuania's deputy prime minister, has been nominated to the new post of party chairman, it said. Lithuania declared its independence from the Soviet Union in March. Its leadership, along with that of its Baltic neighbors, Latvia and Estonia, has said it will not sign a Union Treaty proposed by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The treaty would preserve the unity of the 15 Soviet republics under strong central control.

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop: Masterminds of Jesuit Massacre May Never Be Charged
DOC.TEXT: A judge's decision to close the investigation into the massacre of six Jesuit priests could mean the masterminds will never be punished, a Roman Catholic archbishop said Sunday. ``There was not just one mastermind, there are more,'' Monsignor Arturo Rivera Damas, the archbishop of San Salvador, told reporters after Sunday Mass. Judge Ricardo Zamora on Friday closed his investigation into the Nov. 16, 1989, murders of six Jesuit priest-professors, their housekeeper and her 15-year-old daughter. He ordered Col. Guillermo Benavides, three lieutenants and four soldiers to stand trial. Judicial sources say closing the investigation makes it highly unlikely anyone else will be prosecuted for the crime. The Jesuits, Roman Catholic leaders and members of the U.S. Congress who have been monitoring the inquiry contend Benavides is not the only one behind the killings. Rep. Joe Moakley. D-Mass., and the Rev. Jose Maria Tojeira, head of the Jesuits in Central America, have accused members of the Salvadoran army command of obstructing the investigation, covering up evidence and lying to the judge. Tojeira said the United States and the armed forces had pressured the judge into closing his inquiry before anyone else was implicated. Benavides, he said, acted at the behest of ``a powerful group within the armed forces.'' Rivera Damas said everyone involved in the massacre should be brought to justice. He said moving the case into the trial phase ``is an error because there are others who should also be punished.'' ``I think the (Jesuits are) right to disagree with the judge's decision. I disagree, too,'' Rivera Damas said. Benavides is the highest-ranking Salvadoran officer ever charged with a human rights crime. No officer has been convicted of a human rights crime throughout a decade of civil war in which human rights groups estimate that 30,000 people died at the hands of death squads linked to the military and the right-wing. The Jesuit case has put U.S. policy in El Salvador in the spotlight. Critics say Washington, which has poured billions of dollars into El Salvador since the war with leftist rebels began in 1980, has tolerated massive human rights abuses by the armed forces. The far right, including many army officers, despised the Jesuits for their support for a negotiated end to the war and their belief that it stemmed from repression, poverty and injustice rather than an international communist conspiracy. Two of the lieutenants accused in the case have testified that Benavides ordered the slayings and the elimination of any witnesses. Benavides denies the charges.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Snow Hits France, Spain, Switzerland
DOC.TEXT: Storms dumped heavy snow Sunday in Western Europe, knocking out services in parts of France, Spain and Switzerland. Seven people were reported dead from an earlier blizzard in Britain and Northern Ireland. ``Winter has come with a vengeance,'' said a spokesman for the London Weather Center. ``Conditions are going to be quite nasty.'' Police said at least four people have died in the freezing conditions and snow that hit much of northern and central England on Saturday. Three more died on roads in Northern Ireland, which was battered by gale force winds, they said. Snow and ice made many British roads impassable Sunday, major rail services were cut and hundreds of thousands of homes were without electricity and water supplies. Helicopters rescued drivers stranded along roadways in sub-freezing temperatures. In central France, the first winter snow cut electricity and made driving hazardous. High winds and rain swept the Cote d'Azur and the French Mediterranean island of Corsica, officials said. Heavy snowfalls in northern Spain forced traffic officials to close dozens of mountain passes. Snow in Tessin state in southern Switzerland closed Lugano airport and disrupted rail traffic, local officials said. The London Weather Center spokesman said the cold front that had dumped snow on France was moving across Belgium and heading for southeast England, bringing icy winds from the Arctic and ``a packet of snow.'' British weathermen predicted more snow for northern and central England and said icy winds from Europe could extend the arctic freeze to the southeast. Police in County Durham in the north said helicopters had rescued more than 274 drivers trapped in their cars on a major route across the Pennine mountain range. A helicopter with a paramedic on board set down at the snowbound Oxfordshire home of Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd to pick up his 7-year-old son, Philip, and take him to a hospital for treatment of suspected appendicitis. The British army was called out late Saturday to help utility workers in the Midlands repair power lines cuts that have left half a million people without power, some for more than 24 hours. In Yorkshire in northern England, about 200,000 people were without electricity, utility companies said. Power supplies to homes in Leicestershire and Oxfordshire were also hit, said local officials.

DOC.HEAD: Caretaker Government Explores Sending Ershad Into Exile
DOC.TEXT: The 3-day-old caretaker government is considering sending ousted President Hussain Muhammad Ershad into exile, politicians said Sunday. The major opposition parties demanded on Friday, one day after Ershad left office, that the ex-president be tried on charges of corruption and misusing power during his eight-year rule. But Shahabuddin Ahmed, the caretaker president, has approached the party blocs for their reaction to the idea of letting Ershad leave the country, a political source said on condition of anonymity. The public response from the main political alliances was negative. Ershad, a former general who seized power in 1982, resigned following a seven-week campaign for his ouster led by university students and the opposition political parties. He remained secluded in his well-guarded home Sunday. Several other members of his government were in hiding, fearing they might be attacked if they appear in public. Sheik Hasina, head of the Awami League, reacted cautiously to the suggestion of sending the president into exile. ``The man or institution which has done the wrong thing must get punishment. But it must be by law,'' she told foreign reporters. When pressed about Ershad's case, however, she added: ``If he leaves the country, at least our people will be relieved.'' Khaleda Zia, leader of the Bangladesh Nationlist Party, insisted on prosecuting the deposed president. ``There should be charges against him. The interim government should start (the procedings). It should arrest him,'' said Mrs. Zia in an interview. ``I don't think the people will allow it,'' she said when asked if Ershad should be exiled. Shahabuddin, the former chief justice of the Supreme Court, has said his job as acting president is to maintain law and order and set up elections. He said he would take no major policy decisions. Moudud Ahmed, Ershad's vice president, accused the political groups of pushing for immediate trials to block Ershad's Jatiya Party from contesting the elections. ``I don't mind facing charges if there is a fair trial on specific charges. But not if it is to intimidate,'' he told a reporter at his luxurious Dhaka home. ``I believe this is being done for political purposes.'' Moudud also said corruption trials should be extended to civil servants and to members of previous administrations that governed Bangladesh after it won independence from Pakistan in 1971.

DOC.HEAD: Tenor John Alexander Dies Aged 67
DOC.TEXT: John Alexander, a tenor with the Metropolitan Opera for 27 years who was renowned for his interpretation of 19th-century bel canto roles, died of a heart attack, authorities said Sunday. He was 67. Alexander collapsed Saturday evening at the Temple Theater in his hometown of Meridian and was taken to Jeff Anderson Regional Medical Center where he was pronounced dead of a massive heart attack, said Lauderdale County Medical Examiner Marl Cobler. Alexander recently retired after 27 years as a leading tenor with New York's Metropolitan Opera. He was an Opera Hall of Fame member who had performed with orchestras worldwide. Alexander was the first American-born tenor to establish a worldwide reputation for his masterful interpretation of 19th-century bel canto roles, a style of singing that is characterized by brilliant vocal display and purity of tone and most often associated with Italian artists. ``John was a first-class artist and absolute gentlemen at all times,'' said Franklin Choset, former artistic director and general manager of the Mississippi Opera. ``In our profession, that is a lot more than can be said about people of all his stature. ``It's a loss for the entire opera world and I extend my sympathies to John's family,'' Choset said from his home in Tel Aviv, Israel. Alexander was among a group of artists from Meridian performing for about 1,500 people at the Centennial Pops celebration, a fund-raiser for the Grand Opera House. Other featured artists included baritone Julian Patrick, soprano Gail Robinson and baritone Andrew Gainey, all former Meridian residents known to audiences of the New York City and Metropolitan opera companies. ``He was one of the nicest, warmest and most generous colleagues,'' Patrick said in a statement. ``He was one of the most Christian men you could hope to know. We were old, old friends.'' Alexander trained at the Cincinnati Conservatory after pre-medical studies at Duke University and service with the U.S. Air Force. His most influential teacher was the baritone Robert Weede. In 1952, he made his debut as Faust with the Cincinnati Opera. Five years later, he joined the New York City Opera as Alfredo. In 1961, he became a member of the Metropolitan Opera as Ferrando.

DOC.HEAD: Drunk Soldier Drives Home - In a Tank
LaserPhoto VIE4
DOC.TEXT: Police thought they had made the streets safer by taking away Gregor Hajek's driver's license. But the 29-year-old soldier was back on Vienna streets hours later Sunday - with a tank. ``I wanted to go home,'' Hajek told police shortly after climbing out of the M60 tank following a 35-mile drive from a town south of Vienna that ended near his parents home in the Austrian capital. Police said the man had been charged with resisting state authority and numerous traffic violations. Resisting state authority carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison. En route the driver had tried to ram one squad car attempting to stop him, ignored several warnings to stop, and drove through a series of red lights. A police car, siren wailing to warn other drivers, had followed the tank on the last part of the journey. Police said the drama began late Saturday and gave the following account: Hajek's car was stopped for a routine check and police decided he was drunk. They took his license and drove him back to his barracks in the village of Zwoelfaxing, south of Vienna. Hajek, however, had access to the keys of his M60 tank. Guards heard a tank starting up shortly after midnight but were unable to stop the vehicle, which crashed through locked gates and headed down the freeway toward Vienna. Two officers tried to stop the vehicle shortly after it entered city limits but got out of the way when the tank charged toward them. ``Further attempts to stop him also were in vain,'' a police report said. The tank, which moved at 30 mph, finally stopped on the street where Hajek's parents live. ``So he actually almost did make it home,'' a police spokesman said dryly. He spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: President Skips `Christmas in Washington' Taping
DOC.TEXT: An exhausted President Bush stayed home Sunday night, skipping plans to a attend a Christmas celebration. Bush returned Saturday from a weeklong trek through South America, his third foreign journey in as many weeks. He looked drawn Sunday morning at a church service, his only public appearance. With the capital enjoying Indian summer-like weather, Bush spent the afternoon on the White House tennis court, and the exercise left him ``a little under the weather afterwards,'' John Herrick, a White House press aide, said. ``He's just feeling a little exhausted.'' Bush cancelled plans to attend the taping of a gala ``Christmas in Washington'' television show at the Pension Building. First lady Barbara Bush, who passed up the five-nation South American trip, went without him. Bush has a full schedule Monday, including meetings with President Vytautas Lansbergis of Lithuania and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, and a Christmas ball at the White House in the evening for members of Congress. That will kick off a string of eight Christmas parties the Bushes will host over the next two weeks for several thousand guests.

DOC.HEAD: Martinucci Excites as Chenier at Met
DOC.TEXT: Nicola Martinucci excited the audience in the title role of the Metropolitan Opera's first ``Andrea Chenier'' of the season. It is the only role the Italian tenor is singing at the Met this season. Aprile Millo and Sherrill Milnes, also starring, were in top form Saturday as was conductor Julius Rudel and the Metropolitan Opera orchestra and chorus. Martinucci sang with round, open tones, ringing on top. Much of the music in this Giordano opera, set in the French Revolution, is impassioned. Martinucci sang it with strong passion. After both his big Act 1 aria and first duet with Millo, applause was sustained. He sounded a little tired in the last two acts but his singing was still eloquent and his top notes continued to ring out heroically. There is lovely, lush music in ``Andrea Chenier,'' which seems to be a more popular opera in Europe than America. The Met last performed it in 1976-77. Maddalena, daughter of a countess, falls in love with Andrea Chenier, a poet. Gerard, a servant in her house, is in love with her. He waffles about getting Chenier out of the way by denouncing him; Milnes sings his big aria in a bright, warm voice. He finally testifies in Chenier's favor at his trial. But Chenier is sent to the guillotine anyway. Maddalena goes with him. Millo sang with a lush tone, while the orchestra's melody swelled beneath her voice. And she held some ravishing high pianissimos and, when appropriate, sang with a sweetly pensive tone. Andrea Velis sang an appropriately weasily spy. The third act aria for the blind woman, giving her young grandson to be a soldier, is written to pull the heartstrings and Camellia Johnson presented it effectively. It is the first set designed by Austrian Wolfram Skalicki at the Met.

DOC.HEAD: Female Mystery Writers Show Crime Makes No Gender Distinctions
DOC.TEXT: They've gotten away with murder, but only on the pages of their books. Boston-based mystery writers Linda Barnes, Susan Kelly, Jane Langton and Katherine Hall Page are among the women who continue to make inroads in the territory carved out by Arthur Conan Doyle and Raymond Chandler, among others. Moreover, their protagonists - whether amateurs puzzled by the death of a friend or full-fledged private detectives - are named Liz or Carlotta, instead of Sam or Sherlock. ``Women mystery writers are getting more attention,'' said Kate Mattes, owner of Kate's Mystery Books in Cambridge. ``They go into areas that men can't.'' Over the weekend, a number of New England-based mystery writers gathered at Kate's to greet fans and compare notes on murder and mayhem. Hot-pink copies of Barnes' latest Carlotta Carlyle mystery, ``Coyote,'' were thrust at the author for autographs - which pleased the writer who was once told by her publisher that writing a mystery with a female detective ``would be death.'' Barnes, an established author of the ``Michael Spraggue'' series, said: ``There were no detectives at that time that behaved the way I felt a real woman would.'' After a short story featuring Carlotta - a 6-foot, redheaded, part-time cabbie and part-time private eye - proved to be a hit, three novels followed. Barnes sees no limit to the public appetite for female detectives. ``That's a question that Tony Hillerman or Robert Parker doesn't have to answer,'' she said, referring to two well-known mystery writers. ``Most mystery fans read a lot of books. I can't write a book a day. But many of my readers read a book a day.'' Cambridge-based author Kelly says female detectives are overcoming credibility problems with male readers, and publishers, who once couldn't believe a woman could handle a gun or peer into the twisted canyons of a psychopath's mind. Kelly's creation, Liz Connors, is a free-lance crime writer who lives in Cambridge. ``Until Proven Innocent'' is her latest adventure. Liz is a tough customer, who can handle herself in a life-and-death situation, thanks to creator Kelly who has taught police-report writing at police academies and counts a forensic pathologist among her frequent dinner guests. But not all female mystery writers have female protagonists. Langton of Lincoln writes meticulously researched mysteries often set in well-known New England locations, such as ``Murder at the Gardner,'' set in the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum. A soft-spoken lady with gray hair, she shudders when asked about how she likes murdering her victims, saying earnestly: ``I'm a terribly nice lady. I like solving some puzzles. I hate to bother with real, actual police work.'' An upcoming book will feature a battle between developers and conservationists, she said. Page's feisty culinary expert Faith Sibley Fairchild is a minister's wife, with a baby in tow, who begins to solve mysteries to fight housebound boredom. In ``The Body in the Kelp,'' she finds clues in a family quilt. Susan Conant, who also trains dogs, has developed Holly Winter, a dog trainer who finds herself tracking down killers in ``A New Leash on Death'' and ``Dead and Doggone,'' both aimed at dog lovers and mystery fans. ``As a mystery reader, I found myself reading mysteries by women written with strong women characters,'' she said. ``To a certain extent, I like to write those books I like to read.'' If there is any pattern to female detective fiction, it is that while male hard-boiled detectives are loners, even single female detectives ``have some kind of family around them, although it's not a traditional husband and kids,'' Barnes said. ``It's more the way that women live, that friendships are important,'' she said. ``Carlotta is not concerned with justice as maintaining relationships. She's concerned about what's going to happen after the books end.''

DOC.HEAD: Troops Dismantle Camp of Former Libyan POWs
DOC.TEXT: Troops of the new government Sunday began dismantling a well-armed camp allegedly used by U.S.-trained Libyan war prisoners to destabilize Libyan ruler Col. Moammar Gadhafi, a French report said. Agence France-Presse, a news service, reported the camp about six miles north of the capital of N'Djamena was well-stocked with Soviet-made weaponry and other arms and communications equipment. The United States evacuated about 600 Libyan POWs from Chad to Nigeria on Friday and Saturday after Idriss Deby's rebel forces toppled President Hissene Habre earlier this month. Deby is now interim president. Other former POWs returned to Libya, which helped arm Deby's fighters. But the U.S. ambassador to Chad, Richard Bogosian, has declined to comment on news reports that the soldiers were trained by U.S. military advisers for commando operations against Libya. The AFP report referred to the former POWs as ``Libyan Contras.'' Chadian forces captured the Libyan fighters in clashes in 1983 and 1987. Chad and Libya have been battling periodically in a border dispute for more than 20 years. The camp, surrounded by six-foot walls topped with barbed wire, contained Soviet anti-tank missiles, sophisticated radio equipment and about 300 Toyota all-terrain vehicles as well as some mounted canons, the French news agency reported. The camp had been guarded by French marines since the POWs were evacuated, AFP reported. Also Sunday, Libya's foreign minister met with Nigerian President Gen. Ibrahim Babangida in efforts to return the rest of the former POWs to Libya, the official Libyan news agency JANA reported. After the meeting in Lagos, Nigeria, Foreign Minister Ibrahim Bashari of Libya said of the evacuated POWs, ``Those who are in this situation are held against their will. ``They were taken hostage because they have a lot of information. They were trained and armed to destabilize the government of their own country or the political system of other nations.'' Reports last week said the POWs were flown to Nigeria. On Sunday, however, reports said the Libyans' final destination was believed to be Zaire. On Sunday, Libya also claimed France had a hand in the airlift of the prisoners. A spokesman at the French Foreign Ministry refused to comment on the Libyan accusations. Chad gained independence from France in 1960.

DOC.HEAD: Widow-Turned-Nun Becomes Canada's First Native Saint
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Sunday canonized Marguerite d'Youville, a 18th-century widow-turned-nun who is Canada's first native saint. Her Sisters of Charity, the order she founded in 1737, operates in Canada and the United States within schools, hospitals and other social service agencies. It is particularly known for its work at d'Youville College in Buffalo, New York. Nuns from the order or its branches also serve in Haiti, Brazil, Japan and Africa. The saint's seventy years were marked by suffering and hardship. She was born Marguerite Dufrost in Varennes, Quebec. Her father died when she was seven. At 21, she married Francois d'Youville, who was frequently away from home selling liquor. Four of her six children died in infancy. One of them, a newborn, died a few days after her husband in 1730, leaving her a widow at age 29. When her two sons entered the seminary in 1737, she and three other women founded the Institute of the Sisters of Charity, consecrating themselves to the service of God, the sick and the forgotten poor. In his homily during the canonization Mass in St. Peter's Basilica, the pope said the new saint's life showed how one can be holy every day and how one can make the ``charity and justice of God'' triumph in daily existence. In April, the pope signed a decree attributing the cure of a patient suffering from leukemia to the intercession of d'Youville. Lisa Normand of Gatineau, Quebec, was cured in 1983. A certified miracle is required for saints who were not martyrs.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Reject Referendum, But It Could Be Implemented by Judge
DOC.TEXT: The narrow defeat of a referendum designed to help minorities win City Council seats could throw the issue back to a federal judge who has vowed to impose either the same plan or a similar one, officials say. Voters on Saturday rejected by just 369 votes a referendum that would have created a system to elect 14 council members by individual districts and elect the mayor at large. Under the current system instituted in 1975, eight council members are elected by voters in individual districts and another three, including the mayor, are elected by voters citywide. Proponents of the plan rejected Saturday said they would seek a recount because of the slim margin. The final vote was 45,255 in favor of the plan and 45,624 against it. Supporters said the proposed voting system would have helped ease racial inequities that make it difficult for minorities to get elected. Opponents said the system would have resegregated Dallas. They backed a plan voters approved in August 1989, calling for 10 candidates to be elected by district and four by region and for the mayor to be elected by voters citywide. That earlier proposal never was implemented because a federal judge suggested he would rule it unconstitutional. Now that voters have rejected the plan, U.S. District Judge Jerry Buchmeyer could call a May election to institute the same plan or a similar one in which 15 council members would be elected by individual district and the mayor would be chosen from among the council. ``I assume the judge is going to do what he said he would do, which is call the election,'' Dallas Mayor Annette Strauss told The Dallas Morning News. Mrs. Strauss was quoted Sunday as saying the judge had indicated he could make the ruling as early as January. It was unclear what the council would do. ``We're waiting for Buchmeyer to make a ruling,'' said Councilman Jim Buerger. ``We have no alternative but to wait for the judge. This issue has been unresolved for decades.'' The referendum was held as part of the settlement of a 1988 federal lawsuit brought by Roy Williams and Marvin Crenshaw, who failed in their at-large council bids. The men, both black, charged the existing election system made it difficult for minorities to win election. Black and Hispanic leaders nationwide have long charged that at-large elections dilute minority candidates' political power and make it difficult for them to win office.

DOC.HEAD: Tractor-Trailers Burned; Police Attribute Arson to Daily News Strike
With AM-Daily News
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen tractor-trailer cabs were damaged in an arson fire and five others were vandalized Sunday at a company that provides paper to the Daily News, authorities said. No injuries were reported. Police believe the attack on the Baldwin Transportation Co. trucks was related to the 6{-week-old strike at the newspaper. Investigators found a hole cut in the chain-link fence around the parking lot in the Bronx section, said Lt. Frank Martinez, a Fire Department spokesman. Fire marshals also determined chemicals were used to set the 14 cabs on fire early Sunday, he said. Another five trucks had their windshields smashed, he said. Meanwhile, Nassau County police reported two incidents of strike-related vandalism. Two stores on suburban Long Island that sell the News had their doorknobs and locks jammed with unknown substances, police said. Bumper stickers saying ``Boycott the Daily News'' were put on their doors. After Sunday's incidents, News spokesman John T. Sloan asked union leaders to stop what he described as a ``desperate campaign of violence.'' The News has continued to publish, using management, replacement workers and union members who have crossed the picket line since the strike began Oct. 25. Its circulation has dropped by more than half, to about 500,000, and major advertisers have deserted the paper. Publisher James Hoge has charged the unions with waging a conspiracy of violence against replacement workers and News dealers and distributors. Union leaders have denied any organized conspiracy and denounced the acts of violence. Bernard D. DeLury, the director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, has invited both sides to meet with him in Washington this week. Sloan said officials at the paper will call federal officials ``first thing Monday morning'' to arrange a date and time. George McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trade Council, a union umbrella group, issued a statement Sunday calling the meeting, ``the most important meeting in the two-year history of the labor dispute.'' On Tuesday, Hoge will go to Chicago to appear before the board of directors of the News' parent company, the Tribune Co. The board is meeting for the first time since the strike began.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Takes Shevardnadze To Hometown For Arms Talks
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III took the Soviet foreign minister to his hometown Sunday and predicted they would make progress on a wide range of issues, including the search for a treaty to cut long-range nuclear weapons. While the crisis in the Persian Gulf demands their attention, Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze hope to clear roadblocks to a Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty. ``I have no doubt that our talks here in Houston will be productive and that we will continue to tackle some difficult issues in a constructive spirit,'' Baker said. He and Shevardnadze plan two days of talks on the treaty, the gulf situation and other U.S.-Soviet issues. They also intend to visit the Johnson Space Center and talk to the Columbia astronauts aboard the Shuttle through a special telephone hookup. But if the mission is cut short because of poor weather or trouble with disposing of liquid waste that colorful interlude may have to be scratched. Baker, in an arrival statement at Ellington air field, praised the Soviets for cooperating with the United States in trying to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. ``On no issue has U.S.-Soviet cooperation been more necessary than on resolving the crisis caused by Iraq's brutal aggression,'' Baker said. A few hours before Baker and Shevardnadze arrived on separate planes, a group of hostages were brought home by former Texas Gov.
