John Connally. ``They never should have been taken hostage in the first place,'' Baker said. ``So while we are heartened by their return, we will not rest until all hostages from all nations are safely home.'' The treaty to reduce U.S. and Soviet long-range nuclear bombers, missiles and submarines by about 30 percent is nearly finished. The remaining unsettled issues deal mostly with verification - procedures to assure compliance with the restrictions to be imposed. When it is finished, President Bush plans to go to Moscow to sign the treaty at a summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Shevardnadze, in a brief statement, said in Russian ``it seems we have a lot of work ahead of us.'' Noting that the United States and the Soviet Union have cooperated in some space ventures, the foreign minister remarked: ``I hope we will further solidify our cooperation on earth.''

DOC.HEAD: Sunny or Partly Cloudy Skies Across Most of Nation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT to EST sted EDT.
DOC.TEXT: Fair weather prevailed across much of the nation Sunday, but rain dampened parts of northwest California, Oregon, Washington, Idaho and Montana. There were no reports of heavy rainfall or measurable snowfall during the 6 hours ending at 1 p.m. EST. Locally heavy rain late Saturday and early Sunday caused flooding at Hilo, Hawaii. Gale warnings were in effect Sunday over Lake Huron, North Carolina's coastal waters and the Washington-Oregon coast. Highs were in the 50s and 60s in parts of the Midwest, including 50 in Des Moines, Iowa; 52 in Indianapolis, Ind., 56 in Chicago and 62 in St. Louis, Mo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. ranged from 25 degrees at Jackson, Wyo., to 84 degrees at Oceanside, Calif. High temperature records broken or tied Sunday included 54 in Alpena, Mich.; 50 in Marquette, Mich.; 47 in Duluth, Minn.; 45 in International Falls, Minn.; and 56 in Fargo, N.D. Hollywood, Fla., cooled to 45 degrees Sunday morning, breaking the city's low temperature record for the date. The coldest spot in the nation Sunday morning was West Yellowstone, Mont., which hit 8 degrees below zero.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Wins Polish Presidency in Landside
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 25 grafs to UPDATE with latest returns, turnout, details from scene in Gdansk. Picks up 26th graf pvs, `For Walesa...'
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa, the shipyard worker who helped lead his country out of Communism, swept to a landslide victory in Poland's first popular presidential vote Sunday, according to partial returns. Walesa defeated emigre businessman Stanislaw Tyminski, a virtual unknown before the campaign, by 75 percent to 25 percent, according to the first official results from 165 of the country's more than 22,000 polling stations, the television said. Full official results were expected late Monday, but earlier exit polls predicted a similar outcome. ``There are terribly difficult tasks waiting for us,'' Walesa said as he sipped a congratulatory glass of champagne before the television cameras and supporters in Gdansk, where his Solidarity movement began in August 1980. ``I hope that we will be building Poland's future together. I want to behave firmly, I want to firmly correct everything that is wrong, and make firm accounts for everything that has not been accounted for yet.'' Outside, thousands gathered and chanted his name over and over. They sang ``Sto Lat,'' a song that means, ``May You Live 100 Years.'' Tyminski declined to concede defeat immediately, saying he did not trust the polls. He said he would remain active in Polish politics. Outgoing President Wojciech Jaruzelski, who sent Walesa to jail under martial law nine years ago, sent his congratulations. He wished the new president ``fruitful activity for the good of our homeland.'' Turnout was estimated at 53 percent, compared with about 60 percent in the first round last month, according to preliminary results. The Solidarity leader and 1983 Nobel Peace Prize laureate had asked voters to give him a broad mandate to lead the country to a market economy and a European-style democracy. The exit polls showed that he did well among all social groups - nearly doubling the 40 percent he got in the first round in November. Tyminski, who performed well in the first round, appeared to have been damaged by numerous questions raised about him at the end of the campaign. ``I'm surprised, but I won't make any comments at the moment,'' Tyminski told reporters after inspecting the returns posted at his home voting district in Pecice, outside Warsaw. Walesa had split the Solidarity movement when he opposed Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki in the first round of voting Nov. 25. But this time, he ran with the backing of the powerful Roman Catholic Church and virtually all political and social organizations. ``I voted for Walesa. How could anyone vote for a clown?'' said Jan Grzesiak, 52, a Warsaw building superintendent. ``Walesa is a worker, he went through hardship and he is an honest man - contrary to Tyminski.'' Tyminski, a self-proclaimed millionaire, beat Mazowiecki in the first round based on his promise to bring Western business know-how to Poland and improve the economy in a month. Although he returned to Poland in September after 21 years in Canada and Peru, there were reports that he had ties with former Communist and police operatives. Tyminski's political tract, ``Sacred Dogs,'' was co-written with an ex-correspondent for a Communist Party daily, and he acknowledged that several ranking campaign aides were party members or secret-police veterans. Also, he failed to clearly explain how he would carry out his promise to improve the economy. And questions were raised about his claimed mystical experiences in the Amazon jungle. Tyminski, 42, who owns computer-related and communications businesses and leads the fringe Libertarian Party of Canada, had railed against the economic ``treason'' of Mazowiecki. He appealed especially to young voters not under the spell of the Solidarity legend and eager for financial success. He also found votes among farmers, miners and others threatened by the government's tight-money and profit-or-perish market policies. The winner could be inaugurated for a five-year term as early as this weekend if the results are not contested. The president's early tasks include nominating a prime minister to succeed Mazowiecki, who has asked to resign, and overseeing the country's first fully free parliamentary elections since World War II next year. Walesa said Sunday night he is considering seven candidates to succeed Mazowiecki and expects to decide by Wednesday. For Walesa, 47, the victory culminated an astonishing personal voyage: from the child of a dirt-poor peasant family to a shipyard electrician dismissed for union organizing; from union leader to political prisoner to presidential candidate. Walesa has promised to carry out the same basic aims as Mazowiecki. But he says he will change the nation's tough economic reform program to ease problems of farmers and to try to create jobs for the unemployed. He says he would be faster and more effective than Mazowiecki because he is able and willing to talk to common people. ``I am not afraid to confront the masses when I am right. I may even confront the whole of Poland,'' he said. ``Like it or not, I do not want to please everybody.''

DOC.HEAD: Freed American Hostage Says He Wants to Go to Saudi Arabia
With AM-Gulf-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: After four months hiding from Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait, Joseph Lammerding of California said Monday he would like to join American forces in Saudi Arabia. Lammerding, 35, was the first of 175 Americans leaving a U.S.-chartered Iraqi Airways jumbo jet after it landed in Frankfurt. It left Baghdad on Sunday with the first Americans to depart under an Iraqi order to release all foreigners. ``Now I just want to see Mom and Dad,'' said Lammerding, a native of Sacramento, Calif. ``I hope to be back in Saudi Arabia next month. He said he would like to be part of the effort to push Iraq out of Kuwait. A slight, bearded man in jeans who carried only a small canvas bag, Lammerding identified himself as an adviser to the Kuwaiti military who had lived in the oil-rich nation since 1983. Lammerding, three other Americans, and one Briton fled at night to a villa outside Kuwait City after the Iraqi invasion Aug. 2. They remained there for more than four months. The group learned they were free to leave Saturday night, one day after the Iraqi parliament approved a decree by President Saddam Hussein allowing all foreigners to go home. Recalling his experience, Lammerding described Iraqi brutality accompanied by a low level of military professionalism. ``Sometimes they (Iraqis) would shoot one member of a family. Sometimes the entire family. They raped and plundered, literally,'' he said of the treatment of Kuwaitis. He said Kuwaitis did their best to hamper Iraqi efforts to keep control of the country by tearing down street signs and house nubers, making it difficult for the Iraqis to get around. Nighttime visits by Kuwaitis with food and medical supplies helped his group survive when their own food supplies ran out several weeks after the invasion. The small band of foreigners refused to answer the door when Iraqi soldiers who had moved into a neighboring villa rang the bell. ``We played kind of dumb,'' said Lammerding. Lammerding gave high marks to U.S. policy in the Persian Gulf. ``Many of us feel the U.S. government has done a good job, especially utilizing the United Nations,'' Lammerding said. He said Washington should keep up the pressure on Saddam.

DOC.HEAD: Father Stands Up for Marine Son in Desert Shield
DOC.TEXT: Marine Sgt. Paul Flemmer is somewhere in the Persian Gulf, but he and the former Rhonda McWilliams were married here over the weekend anyway. Flemmer's father, Del Flemmer, stood in for his eldest son under a state provision that allows proxy weddings. ``I haven't got married for 30 years,'' the elder Flemmer quipped just before exchanging vows Saturday with his daughter-in-law-to-be, Rhonda McWilliams, 25, of nearby Stevensville. The wedding was arranged by mail, telephone and a legal power-of-attorney. ``Usually, when the groom doesn't show up for the wedding, the wedding is off,'' said the Rev. Gale Fister, who conducted the ceremony at Lolo Community Church. Flemmer and Miss McWilliams, who have a 1-year-old son, were scheduled to be married Aug. 30 and Flemmer had been granted a 30-day leave for the occasion. The couple had even purchased a house in Stevensville, the 25-year-old bride's home. Flemmer's leave was canceled abruptly after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. He was sent from his duty station at El Toro, Calif., to the Persian Gulf on Aug. 27. But the bride was determined to have a wedding, with or without the groom. ``We'd heard about the possibility of a proxy wedding, but the (Marine Corps) chaplain in California said it couldn't be done,'' she said. Montana is one of the few states that allows proxy weddings. The power of attorney gave Paul's father the legal right to act as his son's deputy or agent. Family members said they would send Flemmer newspaper clippings, a tape recording, a videotape and photos of the wedding. ``When Paul gets back, we'll do it the right way,'' his bride said.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Walesa's First Post-Election Message
DOC.TEXT: Here is a text of a message to Poles by Lech Walesa broadcast nationwide after early election returns indicated a landslide presidential victory Sunday. The translation was done by the Polish Press Agency: The elections are over. Another lesson of democracy is behind us. We can thank and congratulate one another. Over the past decade we have together experienced a breakthrough in the history of our nation. Dreams of entire generations have become true before our eyes. We have regained freedom. Providence has given us the privilege of finding peaceful solutions. Without blood, through solidarity in action, we have won a free Poland. It depends entirely on us what we will do with it in the future. This was forgotten many a time during this (presidential) campaign. Tremendous responsibility will rest with the president. It also rests with us all. Everyone should start to feel like a host in our common house, have a tiny part of Poland, his own property which he will respect and care for. This is the simplest philosophy of responsibility. No professional group, no man will be able to say: `There are no prospects for me.' In Poland there is enough work for everyone. We must change and modernize much. This is a new task for intelligentsia. We must first help ourselves. Europe will appreciate us for this. An economically developed Poland will be one of the pillars of peace and calm in Europe, whereas a poor Poland will meet a wall of disapproval at all borders. We are facing a difficult task: to trust in ourselves and win a measurable success - a success for everyone. I am confident that we shall do this.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Army Seizes Rebel Headquarters on Voting Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE calling election for M-19, latest election returns; locator for guerrilla base; pickup graf 12 pvs `Officials said....' TRIMS thereafter
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers bombed and captured the main base of Colombia's biggest rebel group Sunday as former guerrillas won a national election for a constitutional assembly. At least 11 people were reported killed in the attack. About 400 soldiers, backed by Israeli K-Fir fighter planes and U.S. Blackhawk helicopter gunships, invaded the main base camp of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known as the FARC, an army report said. The attack came the same day Colombians voted in a national election to choose 70 members of an assembly to rewrite the country's 104-year-old constitution. In a humiliating setback to Colombia's two traditional political parties, the former M-19 rebels, led by Antonio Navarro, had an insurmountable lead late Sunday with 49 percent of the total votereported. The National Elections Office said M-19 had 486,599 votes, or 32 percent of the total. The National Salvation Party, a Conservative Party splinter group led by former presidentital candidate Alvaro Gomez, had 324,997 votes, or 21 percent. The rest of the votes were spread thinly among 800 candidates. The elections office said that only about 25 percent of voters went to the polls. It was the lowest voter turnout for a national election in more than a quarter of a century. It was also the first time in Colombia's history that neither the Liberal Party nor the Conservative Party had dominated voting. The results are likely to underscore the possibility of social upheaval unless the government urgently attends to the needs of the poor. The M-19 laid down its arms nine months ago in exchange for government pardons and the right to form a political party. The attack on the FARC headquarters, called ``Casa Verde,'' left seven soldiers and four air force officers dead, the army communique said. The air force men were killed when their helicopter crashed, the army said. The report did not say how many guerrillas, if any, were killed at the base, about 160 miles south of Bogota. A report by the RCN radio network said as many as 40 insurgents died. Officials said Sunday that six rebels and four soldiers were killed in earlier clashes between the army and other guerrilla groups. Sunday's vote will result in a 70-member constitutional assembly empowered to make major structural reform to government. Changes expected include revamping Colombia's battered court system, adding safeguards to curb congressional corruption, and establishing new civil rights in this country wracked by drug violence. Few people doubt that Colombia's powerful cocaine cartels are donating money to assembly candidates, but it is difficult to measure the traffickers' involvement. Candidates rarely mention the government's 15-month-old war on drug traffickers. ``We are at the doors of the most exceptional opportunity to transform Colombia,'' said President Cesar Gaviria in a nationally televised speech Saturday evening. ``We Colombians can finally devise a way to bring our country the peace which has been so elusive,'' he said. Many voters blame old party bosses for corruption and failing to curb violence that has killed tens of thousands of people in the past decade. ``Navarro's got my vote, not because I like him, but because I can't stand the others,'' said Patricia Sanchez, a Bogota educator. Politicians have dredged up the M-19's violent past to discredit the group among voters, particularly its 1985 takeover of the Palace of Justice in Bogota. That action turned into a battle with the army that left about 100 people dead, including 11 Supreme Court justices. The M-19 became a legitimate party nine months ago after laying down its weapons in exchange for a government pardon. Some Colombians fear the army, which has been fighting guerrilla insurgencies for three decades, would stage a coup if the M-19 took over the constitutional assembly. Navarro, a 41-year-old engineer, has tried to convince voters that his party has never been Marxist and will help guarantee civil rights. Leftist guerrillas disrupted balloting in several isolated incidents, officials said Sunday. Army and police reinforcements were stepped up in major cities Sunday, and the government provided free transportation to polling stations. Colombia's cocaine bosses were blamed for assassinating three candidates before presidential elections in May, including M-19 leader Carlos Pizarro. Navarro replaced him.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Protest U.S. Deployment Outside Awards Dinner
DOC.TEXT: Several thousand anti-war demonstrators rallied Sunday outside a hotel where 101 Americans, including President Bush and four former presidents, were honored for their contributions to America. Neither Bush nor former presidents Ronald Reagan and Richard Nixon, the three targeted by an estimated 3,000 protesters, attended a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel after an awards ceremony at Ellis Island in New York Harbor. Fellow honorees Jimmy Carter and Gerald Ford also did not attend. Bush and the former presidents were to accept Ellis Island Medals of Honor at a ceremony to be scheduled later. ``We're demonstrating because the awards are being given to war makers,'' said Scott Scheffer, a spokesman for the Coalition to Stop U.S. Intervention in the Middle East, which organized the protest. No arrests were reported. Honorees who did attend the ceremony inside the recently renovated immigrant processing center on the island in New York Harbor included singer Melba Moore, actor Telly Savalas, comedian Danny Thomas and Cincinnati Reds manager Lou Piniella. The 101 Americans being honored include the descendants of immigrants, slaves and American Indians and represent 36 different ethnic groups. For many attending Sunday's ceremony, it was their first visit to the hall where immigrants were once processed for entry to the United States. The hall is now part of the American Museum of Immigration, which opened in September. Piniella, who led his team to a World Series victory this year, was greeted with shouts of ``Lou!!'' when he accepted his medal. Miss Moore saluted the Army officers who slipped the medal around her neck, then released a joyful whoop under the American flag. Other medal recipients included native American Indian Chief Oren Lyons of the Onondaga tribe, former Texas Congresswoman Barbara Jordan, Roman Catholic Cardinal Joseph Bernardin of Chicago, CBS news consultant Eric Sevareid and Thomas Pickering, the U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations. Traffic was blocked along a one-block section of Park Avenue during the three-hour demonstration to protest the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Several protesters held up banners reading ``Don't spill oil for blood'' and ``Draft beer not war.'' The deployment of U.S. troops is ``not for democracy. It's about oil,'' said one demonstrator, George Kelly. He said he was a World War II and Korean War veteran and a member of the organization Veterans for Peace. While demonstrators marched outside, Pickering defended Bush's decision to send U.S. troops to the Middle East. ``The president is trying to resolve the situation peacefully,'' Pickering said. ``He has walked the last mile for peace.'' The Ellis Island Medal was first presented in 1986 during the 100th anniversary of the Statue of Liberty by the National Ethnic Coalition of Organizations, which represents 66 of the nation's largest heritage groups.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Hostages Greeted by Cheering Relatives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4 grafs for last graf, `Meanwhile, the ...' to UPDATE with further Connally comments opposing a U.S. military attack.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos HT1, HT3, HT7, HT8
DOC.TEXT: Former hostages from Iraq shouted ``God Bless America!'' and families shrieked with delight as they charged to greet each other across the tarmac at Ellington Air Field on Sunday. Former Treasury Secretary John Connally and Oscar Wyatt, the chairman of Coastal Corp., which financed the trip, also were mobbed by family members who covered their faces with lipstick-marked kisses of thanks and moved the men to tears. Connally later said talks with Saddam Hussein revealed a leader who was ``a very tough man, but he's not a stupid man.'' ``He said to us he had no argument with the American people, and he did not want a war. He wanted peace, but he wanted peace with justice and with dignity,'' Connally said. Twenty-one hostages, three U.S. Embassy employees and seven family members stepped off a Coastal Corp. Boeing 707 before dawn Sunday to nearly 200 cheering relatives and friends. Jackie Nelson, wife of former hostage Bill Nelson of Los Angeles, kissed Wyatt and Connally on the cheek and said: ``God bless you. I can't thank you enough. We're so grateful.'' Nelson, who was held at a munitions plant south of Baghdad, said: ``God Bless America. There's nothing like it. These people are marvelous. They have done things our government can't do and won't do.'' As the ex-hostages got off the plane, former hostage Jim Vine's voice rang out above the other. He was seeing his infant son for the first time. ``Oh my God!'' he shouted as he rushed to throw his arms around his wife, Donna, and son, Evan. The baby was born Sept. 6., barely one month after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Connally and Wyatt said they met with Saddam for 45 minutes in the presidential palace. ``We made an impassioned plea to him, saying to him in effect that we thought he should release all the hostages,'' Connally said. ``Mr. Wyatt said that if indeed there's an armed conflict, the presence of a few hundred hostages would not in any way deter the armed conflict.'' They also told Saddam he was being portrayed ``as a vicious, brutal man, compared to Hitler, and I said the release of the hostages before the Christmas season would clearly show a concern and a compassion,'' Connally said. The men also donated 15 tons of medical supplies, valued at $500,000, to Fellowship on Reconciliation, an Iraqi humanitarian group in Amman. Saddam replied as they parted, ``You will not go home with an empty plane,'' according to Connally. That statement touched off a bureaucratic nightmare, in which hostages scrambled to get exit visas and be transported hundreds of miles from the strategic locations at which they were held to Baghdad. Connally described how one British subject, Peter McCleod of London, arrived on the plane ``in his shirtsleeves, with two pillowcases containing his entire possessions.'' Some hostages who hoped to ride home with Connally and Wyatt - who's done business with the Iraqis for 19 years - were forced to remain because of delays in getting exit visas. None of the hostages are connected with Coastal. The plane left Baghdad Saturday morning, stopped in Shannon, Ireland, to refuel and drop off McCleod, and flew on to Houston. Wyatt and Connally secured the hostages' release before Saddam's proposal Thursday to release all hostages. Later Sunday in Austin, Connally said he opposed a U.S. military attack on Iraq. ``If we become involved in a shooting war in that distant land, it will be tragic indeed,'' he said in a speech to more than 12,000 people at a graduation ceremony at the University of Texas. ``The encounter will be fierce with staggering casualties on both sides.'' The United States could defeat Iraq in battle ``but lose the war,'' he said. Meanwhile, the first Americans to be freed under the decree arrived Sunday in Frankfurt, Germany, on a U.S.-chartered flight from Baghdad. About 175 Americans were among some 325 people aboard the jumbo jet.

DOC.HEAD: Singer Paula Abdul Slightly Injured in Three-Car Crash
DOC.TEXT: Singer Paula Abdul, one of the world's highest-paid entertainers, suffered minor injuries in a three-car crash Sunday, police said. Miss Abdul's 1989 black Jaguar rear-ended another car, triggering a collision with a third car on Laurel Canyon Boulevard in Studio City, 10 miles north of downtown Los Angeles, said police Sgt. Al Zardeneta. She was treated at Medical Center of North Hollywood and later released, said hospital spokeswoman Sherry Reese. The former Los Angeles Lakers cheerleader complained of pains in her head, neck and upper body, Zardeneta said. Miss Abdul's car rear-ended a car driven by Charles Koko, 37, of North Hollywood, Zardeneta said. Koko's car then rammed the back of a third car driven by Katherine Butler, 28, of Newport Beach, he said. Koko and Ms. Butler complained of sore necks but were not taken to a hospital, Zardeneta said. ``We don't know how it happened,'' Zardeneta said. ``There are two options - either she (Miss Abdul) was speeding or she was following too closely.'' Miss Abdul's 1989 debut album, ``Forever Your Girl,'' spawned the hits ``Straight Up,'' ``Cold Hearted'' and ``The Way You Love Me'' and garnered several American Music Awards and MTV video awards. She also choreographed the films ``Coming to America'' and ``The Running Man'' and won an Emmy for her choreography on television's ``The Tracey Ullman Show.'' Miss Abdul ranked 33rd in a list of Forbes magazine's 40 highest-paid entertainers with estimated total gross earnings of $23 million for 1989 and 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Planeload of Hostages Arrives In Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with new quote from American. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Now I....' EDITS thereafter to tighten
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BAG1,2; FRA1
DOC.TEXT: The first Americans freed under Saddam Hussein's order releasing all foreigners arrived in Germany early Monday. Other former hostages prepared to leave Iraq after more than four months under guard or in hiding. Some of the 175 Americans on the U.S.-chartered Iraqi Airways jet that landed in Frankfurt were expected to go to a U.S. Air Force hospital in nearby Wiesbaden. Most planned to return to the United States on Monday. Lorin Hubbard, 66, a Boeing Co. executive held as a ``human shield'' at an ammunition plant 35 miles west of Baghdad, Iraq, said he had waited for bombs to fall. ``We were hoping they'd blow the place up. ... We had no idea when we'd get out,'' he said. ``Nobody knew where we were, as far as I know.'' ``Now I just want to see mom and dad,'' said Joseph Lammerding, 35, a native of Sacramento, Calif. He said he would like to return to the region to help the U.S.-led military effort against Iraq. ``I hope to be back in Saudi Arabia next month,'' said Lammerding, who added that he had worked as a Kuwaiti military adviser. ``This is the first time I have had shoes on in over three months,'' said construction worker Randal Warren, 49, of Charleston, Mo., who said he hid in the top floor of a Kuwaiti apartment building and went barefoot to keep quiet. The flight also carried more than 90 Britons, about 30 Canadians, and former hostages from Ireland, Greece, Austria, Argentina, Denmark, Italy, the Netherlands and Switzerland, said airport officials in Baghdad. In all, 324 people were on the airplane, and more than 250 of them had been stranded since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of the tiny oil-rich emirate of Kuwait. The rest included family members and others. The Iraqi parliament on Friday approved a decree by Iraqi President Saddam to free all foreigners in Kuwait and Iraq. Robert Vinton, 58, of Santa Fe, N.M, said he was picked up in Baghdad on Aug. 18 and held at a refinery south of the city. ``It was like a gulag,'' he said after arriving in Frankfurt. Asked what he wanted most, Vinton replied, ``I think a hamburger.'' U.S. officials said they planned to charter another flight in three or four days to evacuate the rest of the estimated 750 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait. Other flights being arranged included British charters to leave Monday and Tuesday to London, and a flight to Moscow. Airport sources also said hundreds of Vietnamese workers were at the airport awaiting departure. The first foreigners to leave Baghdad under the decree issued by Saddam were a group of about 200 hostages, mostly Italians, who arrived in Rome on Sunday aboard an Italian-chartered jet. Western diplomats complained that Iraqi authorities had thrown up some last-minute bureaucratic roadblocks to the exodus. For example, foreigners in cities other than Baghdad were told they must obtain exit visas from those cities. Those who had been under work contracts were told that Iraqi law requires them to present a letter releasing them from their obligations. Iraq has refused U.S. requests to waive visa requirements for freed hostages, and the processing of the visas alone had been expected to delay some departures for days. However, diplomats said Iraqi officials were working quickly Sunday, processing an estimated 80 exit visas an hour. Twenty-one former American hostages landed in Houston early Sunday after flying out of Baghdad a day earlier aboard a jet chartered by former Treasury Secretary John Connally, who was in Iraq on a private hostage-freeing mission. Their release was arranged prior to Iraq's decree freeing all foreigners. ``God bless America!'' said one of the arriving Americans, Bill Nelson of Los Angeles. Three U.S. Embassy employees in Iraq also were on the flight, along with relatives of the former hostages. About 8,000 Westerners had been detained since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, including about 600 who were held at strategic sites in an effort to deter an attack. Voice of America broadcasts advised Americans in Kuwait, including those who have been in hiding since Iraq's invasion, that they could leave on Sunday's charter flights. But diplomats said it was not immediately clear if Americans who had taken refuge in the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait would be allowed to leave. Iraqi troops have sealed off the embassy since it refused to close in August. U.S. officials said Friday they would evacuate the embassy after all Americans were out of Kuwait. Meanwhile, a London newspaper reported that Iraq has redrawn its border with Kuwait in what could signal plans to withdraw as early as next month. The Observer said Iraq was laying claim to an area of the Rumailah oilfield and the islands of Warba and Bubiyan in the gulf. The report said Iraq has constructed a new international line by building a barbed-wire fence around the southern tip of the oilfield, which extends into northern Kuwait. Saudi Arabian officials denied the report. Iraq has repeatedly linked a resolution of the gulf crisis - including any withdrawal from Kuwait - to the Palestinian issue. But on Saturday night, the U.N. Security Council, facing the threat of a U.S. veto, postponed until Monday discussion of a resolution calling for an eventual international peace conference on the Middle East. In another development, Jordan's King Hussein proposed that a compromise settlement of the gulf crisis could be reached through a conference of Arabs. In a speech, he welcomed President Bush's offer to talk with Iraq, and criticized Arab states for refusing to do so. The Bush administration has said the talks are not meant to be negotiations, but are merely aimed at underscoring the demand that Iraq go along with U.N. resolutions on Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Body of Rocket Creates Flash over Central U.S. Sky
DOC.TEXT: The body of a Soviet rocket created a brilliant flash of light seen by residents of five states as it fell toward Earth early Sunday, officials and witnesses said. People in Oklahoma, Texas, Arkansas, Kansas and Colorado reported seeing the light at about 1:45 a.m. EST. Witnesses described the sighting as a bright, reddish object with a long tail. Some said they could make out its cylinderlike shape. It was the second unusual sky sighting since Friday, when residents in Illinois, Michigan, Kentucky and Ohio saw a dazzling blue-green light that scientists later identified as a fireball - an object similar to a meteor. U.S. Air Force Maj. David Griffard of the North American Aerospace Defense Command identified Sunday's sighting as a Soviet rocket body. The agency is tracking about 6,500 objects in space through the U.S. Space Command's worldwide network of radar and electrical sensors, he said. Griffard said the rocket body disintegrated shortly after it entered the Earth's atmosphere. He said he didn't have any further information about the rocket. Robert Skuy of Tulsa said he pulled his car over Sunday morning to look at what he first took to be an airplane in trouble. ``Then I thought it might have been a missile,'' Skuy said. ``It was weird because it wasn't falling. That's why I thought it was an airplane at first. It was kind of like in orbit. All the other meteorites I've seen have been way high up in the sky.'' Skuy, like other witnesses, said the light appeared to be at the altitude of a low-flying plane.

DOC.HEAD: Angola's Ruling Party Agrees to Give Up Monopoly on Power
DOC.TEXT: Angola's ruling party agreed Sunday to give up its monopoly on power and usher in pluralist democracy in this southern African nation. The moves are expected to boost peace negotiations between the government and U.S.-backed rebels. The 15-year civil war has killed an estimated 350,000 people and wrecked a potentially prosperous economy. The government and rebels are due to meet for a sixth round of peace talks January in Portugal, the former colonial ruler. Rebel leader Jonas Savimbi said last week he would be ready to sign a cease-fire if the ruling party carried through its plans for free elections. The ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, meeting for its third national congress, voted to partially revise the country's constitution to allow the installation of ``multiparty democracy in Angola before the end of March 1991,'' state radio reported. The MPLA, as the party is known by its Portuguese initials, also recommended changing legislation to allow the creation of alternative parties, guarantee rights of expression, religion and association, and freedom of the press. Other changes passed by the 700 congress delegates included economic reforms based on free market principles and private property, as well as the abolition of the death penalty. The rebels have said they want general elections before December 1991, but President Jose Eduardo dos Santos says up to three years will be needed after a cease-fire to organize a free vote. There was no immediate reaction to the congress' decisions from the rebels.

DOC.HEAD: Forests Dwindle in Sarawak
With AM-Loin-Clothed Crusader
DOC.TEXT: Time is running out for saving the dwindling hardwood forests of Sarawak. All virgin timber will be gone in 11 years at the present rate of cutting, according to the latest report on logging in the rich Malaysian state in northern Borneo. No cry of alarm from outraged environmentalists for a change, this warning comes from inside the industry. Experts of the International Tropical Timber Organization blame excessive cutting, pollution and recklessness by inept loggers. The organization represents 19 timber producing nations and 25 consumer countries. Formed in 1986 and based in Yokohama, Japan, it is often caught in the middle. It has been rebuked by conservationists for favoring consumers and by producers for taking a narrow, technical approach to the problem of deforestation. The 207-page report has been circulating privately since May. It has drawn criticism from Malaysian officials and international environmental groups for not delving into the distress caused by loggers to nomadic tribes and other jungle dwellers. In a disclaimer, the study said those who drafted it were ``neither qualified nor empowered to judge on such matters.'' Nearly half of Sarawak's 1.6 million people are from some 20 upland native ethnic groups, commonly known as Dyaks. They traditionally lived with informal systems of land tenure, often without legal titles. The state remains the ultimate land owner and officials have the power to change ownership and convert land from communal to individual control. Some jungle communities are unaware of their changed status until new lease-holders arrive to start felling trees. Chief Minister Abdul Taib Mahmud says logging has upgraded the skills of natives and helped them prosper. However, an earlier ITTO report in 1988 said that timber concessionaires and others who control the industry glean most of the wealth from Sarawak's forests. The current annual cutting rate of about 13 million cubic meters should be reduced by about 4 million cubic meters, the latest report suggests. To prevent erosion and protect stream beds from silting up, logging would have to stop on many steep slopes. It faults the state for not having enough forest managers and says the present system of issuing logging concessions tends to reward companies that damage the forest in their haste to get the wood out. Malaysia supplied two-thirds of the world's tropical hardwood logs last year and half of them came from Sarawak, where forests cover almost 70 percent of the land area in a state that is half the size of France. Most of the logs are shipped to Japan, where many end up as disposable chopsticks or are converted into plywood and used only once, as forms for pouring concrete. Western environmentalists accuse the government of allowing the indiscriminate cutting of rain forests. They charge that polluted rivers, devastated wildlife and displaced tribes are left when the chain saws and bulldozers finish. ``What remains behind is virtually wasteland,'' said a report by Sahabat Alam, the Malaysian branch of Friends of the Earth. Describing the deforestation as catastrophic, the European Parliament in Strasbourg recently urged the European Community ``to impose with immediate effect a moratorium on imports of tropical hardwood from Sarawak.'' Timber is the backbone of Sarawak's commercial economy, fetching about $1 billion a year in export earnings. The industry generates almost half the state government's revenue and employs more than 50,000. All forest area is under state government control. About 11.4 million acres is designated ``permanent forest estate,'' which can be selectively logged but not converted to other uses. An additional 632,583 acres is set aside in national parks or wildlife sanctuaries. A study completed late last year by the World-Wide Fund for Nature (formerly World Wildlife Fund) said Sarawak could retain large tracts of rain forest only if it acted promptly to enforce conservation measures. Among other things, it said loggers seemed to lack procedures to ensure environmental protection for their concessions and the social welfare of the people who dwell in them. For more than a year, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has hit back at foreign critics as ill-informed or self-serving. ``The thinning of the ozone layer is blamed on logging of tropical forests,'' he said. ``The fact that the burning of fossil fuels and release of CFC (chloroflurocarbon) into the atmosphere occur largely in the rich countries are significantly ignored.''

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Herdsman Goes Native in Campaign to Save Borneo Rain Forest
With AM-Malaysia-Logging
DOC.TEXT: The nomads of Sarawak hate bright light. Bruno Manser shares their antipathy after six years under the jungle canopy, squinting and squirming as the TV lights flash for another interview. Manser went native in 1984, leaving the safe streets and clock-work predictability of his native Switzerland to share the perils of life with the Penan of Sarawak, one of the world's last nomadic tribes. He downplayed the rain forest's dangers and isolation in an interview in the Austrian capital before jetting to Paris and a meeting with Danielle Mitterrand, wife of the French president, on how to save the Sarawak jungle from loggers. ``A taxi driver in New York or Los Angeles lives more dangerously than I did,'' he said, dismissing the bounty set on his head by several logging companies. ``And about the only thing I missed in the forest was getting together with Swiss friends and singing in three-part harmony.'' His flight from civilization initially took him to lonely Swiss alpine pastures. There he tended cattle and made cheese - but not for long. ``Even the smallest mountain village has a road,'' the wiry 45-year old said. ``And that road serves as the path for things that we don't need -- things that we are forced to consume.'' Manser never thought he'd leave the rain forest. Now, six months into reacquainting himself with civilization, and near the end of his exhausting crusade, it seems clear he'd rather be back in the jungle. The hunter who could melt into the trees has become the hunted as he tours the world's capitals to gather support for a moratorium on Sarawak logging. There's no place to hide from reporters' questions. ``I'm not here of my own choosing,'' he said. ''I'm here because my Penan friends asked me to be here.'' Environmental organizations say about 70 percent of the forest in Malaysia's Sarawak state has been destroyed since large-scale logging began in the early 1970s. Environmental pressure has slowed denuding of the rain forest in Brazil and elsewhere. But large-scale logging in Sarawak, on the northwest coast of Borneo, continues unabated, the organizations say. About 60 percent of the hardwood harvested goes to Japan, the rest to other industrial countries. Approximately 360 square miles of Sarawak rain forest disappear each year, the environmental groups estimate. They say a particularly diverse environment is being lost, harboring 2,000 species of flowering plants, 475 different birds and 200 different mammals. But rain forest still covers millions of square miles of the earth's surface. Thus, say logging advocates, the Sarawak harvest contributes relatively little to environmentally harmful global warming thought to be accelerating because of the disappearing jungle. The Malaysian government denies that the loggers cause permanent damage, asserting that trees are cut down selectively. But environmentalists and the Penan say that, because of the jungle's tangle, one large tree falling takes most of the surrounding vegetation with it. Bulldozers further mutilate the forest as they drag logs away, leaving the denuded soil to erode. Approximately 300 Penan still roam the woods - holdouts against Malaysian government pressure. After a series of jungle confrontations in the early 1980s with government forces, more than 5,000 other Penan have exchanged their nomadic ways for what the Malaysian government says is a better life of farming. Manser disagreed, describing the settlements as tin-roofed refugee camps seared by the hated tropical sun and with inadequate and dirty drinking water. Hunters and gatherers are ill-suited for a life as rice farmers and belong in the jungle, he argued. ``You really experience a sense of joy, and you see, hear or smell that someone has come back from the hunt with prey,'' he said. ``Everybody is happy, everyone talks and tells stories. It's a lttle bit like paradise.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says He'll Confirm Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge said he will confirm Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp.'s reorganization plan this week, ending five and a half years of litigation and allowing the steelmaker to stay in business. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Warren Bentz in overruled the final objections of the at a hearing Saturday. Wheeling-Pittsburgh, which employs about 7,100 people, has six major plants in western Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia. A lawqyer for the company, M. Bruce McCullough, called the approval ``long overdue.'' Denys Cronin, representing the reorganized company's principal investor, said the plan ``provides a fair result for creditors and shareholders alike. Now it's time to get back to concentrating on the company's business.'' The proposed reorganization plan calls for cash distribution of about $600 million to creditors. Plan proponents say the reorganization is viable and will allow the company to compete. The plan creates two corporations, a holding company chaired by New York investor Ronald LeBow, who bought up 86 percent of the company's secured debt, and an operating arm. Wheeling-Pittsburgh Corporation will be the holding company and Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. will be the operating subsidiary. James T. Gibbons, the company's reorganization planning director, estimates that the company, as an ongoing enterprise, is worth at least $1.1 billion to $1.2 billion. Gibbons said operating income over the next five years is expected to drop somewhat because of the impact of oil price increases. In spite of that, he said, the company plans an aggressive $454 million capital improvement program. The confirmation came after Bentz overruled final complaints from the U.S. Farmers' Home Administration. That came after proponents of the confirmation plan agreed to set aside enough cash and securities in a separate account to satisfy the maximum amount of their claim plus interest, should the maximum be awarded later. FmHA and Equibank together hold about $44.2 million in loans to Wheeling-Pittsburgh. They also claim interest on that sum. Earlier, Bentz overruled Environmental Protection Agency objections to the confirmation, saying any penalties to be imposed later for environmental violations could be worked out in the normal course of the company's business.

DOC.HEAD: Ten-Day Sales: Chrysler Backs Off
DOC.TEXT: In the auto industry, 10-day sales reports have long been considered a necessary evil. They've even been likened to foul-tasting medicine or income tax forms, but one of the Big Three automakers, Chrysler Corp. has decided the necessary evils are perhaps unnecessary. Beginning Jan. 15, Chrysler will no longer will issue sales results three times a month. In moving to put out sales figures only once a month, Chrysler breaks a nearly 50-year-old tradition of reporting sales of North American-made vehicles every 10 days. The old American Motors Corp., which Chrysler bought in 1987, broke the tradition once before, but returned to 10-day statements after numerous leaks came out and corporate officials frequently made low estimates for sales that would be easy to make. After Chrysler announced it would abandon 10-day sales reports, General Motors Corp. said it was studying the move and Ford Motor Co. said it would continue with the current system, for now at least. No. 3 Chrysler said producing the reports was too costly, and they serve ``no major purpose that isn't covered by a monthly report.'' But there's much more to it than that. Since production of Japanese nameplate cars is expanding in the United States, year-to-year sales results of those cars look good, with increases sometimes topping 100 percent. Meantime, the Big Three are wrestling with excess factory capacity and sales are sliding. So Chrysler, with retiring Chrysler Motors Chairman Bennett Bidwell heading the charge, has been moaning about unfair comparisons. GM and Ford, while sympathetic to Chrysler's arguments, haven't complained nearly as much. There have been some arguments that if the Japanese companies reported sales of all cars and trucks, no matter where they are made, every 10 days, Chrysler quickly would jump back on the reporting bandwagon. But there appears to be no chance the Japanese companies will do that. They say sales results can be skewed simply by a delay in a couple of ships coming over from Japan. In January, folks who collect the 10-day numbers, including other automakers, Wall Street analysts and reporters will have to become statistical dentists, trying to yank out numbers as accurately as possible. Industry observers are now trying to come up with computer models that can spit out Chrysler numbers based on production,past sales rates, market shares, incentives and, perhaps, even weather. All of those can affect sales during a given 10-day period. Those in favor of scrapping the 10-day reports say they are of questionable value to begin with. They say incentives move in and out of the marketplace like pistons. Cash rebates can inflate sales in one period and make it look considerably better than the same period a year ago, no matter what the underlying demand may be. In addition, 10 days of selling provides too little information to draw meaningful conclusions or detect trends. Others say the figures can show a lot. For instance, there's no restriction on using the numbers only for year-to-year comparisons. If a company slaps a big incentive on one of its slow-selling vehicles and sales shrink in a 10-day period, the company may start wondering whether it has a turkey on its hands. The bottom line for a lot of number-crunchers is this: Sure the 10-day numbers may not be the most significant in the world, but they're data that give a picture of an important industry.

DOC.HEAD: Signs Point to Deepening Media Recession
DOC.TEXT: Business Week magazine, CBS News and The Wall Street Journal close news bureaus and lay off workers. Employees at the New York Post take a big pay cut to keep the paper running. The sports daily The National quits publishing a Sunday paper. Murdoch Magazines closes the highly touted Men's Life magazine after a single issue. The weak economic environment in which media companies have operated the past year is no longer just a worry for the business office. It has produced a marked decline in advertising, led to tighter travel and expense budgets, and forced layoffs at some companies. The downturn, seen as the worst in 20 years, is expected to be the main topic of discussion this week at a conference for industry analysts sponsored by the investment firm PaineWebber Inc. in New York. Most observers see few signs that conditions will improve soon, especially if the economy worsens. Analyst John Morton said newspapers are in a recession and ``things continue to get worse.'' Broadcast industry analyst Jessica Reif said she doesn't foresee a turnaround in broadcasting ``for another year at least.'' Magazine consultant Martin S. Walker said it appears 1991 will be the second consecutive year of flat to declining ad growth for magazines, which also face higher postal costs. ``There is no evidence yet of an upturn,'' PaineWebber analyst J. Kendrick Noble said about the media business in general. ``It won't improve until 1992.'' Capital Cities-ABC Inc., whose ABC television network is making a strong bid to overtake NBC in the prime-time audience ratings, said in October that ad spending at the network and its seven TV stations was ``significantly weaker'' than a year ago. CBS Inc. chief executive Laurence A. Tisch said in mid-November that the company will have a rare loss in the fourth quarter and lower earnings in 1991. The CBS television network, third in the prime-time ratings, is expected to have an operating loss in 1991, Tisch said. Advertisers' spending in newspapers was up a slim 0.7 percent for the first nine months of the year, according to recent estimates from the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. Morton, who works for the brokerage Lynch Jones & Ryan in Washington, D.C., said newspapers can expect to see advertising demand get even softer. He said help-wanted advertising, for instance, will contract as unemployment rises and real estate ads will slump further as the economy sags. Magazine ad pages were off 3.7 percent for the first 10 months of the year in the 170 consumer magazines surveyed by the Magazine Publishers of America. Publishers face the prospect of postal rate increases of 20 percent or more next year. ``No immediate recovery is in sight,'' Walker said. The media companies are trying to cope by imposing hiring freezes, curbing expenses and, in some cases, laying off workers. Some of them are boosting ad rates or cover prices and are trying to be more creative about attracting ads. CBS has cut 40 to 50 employees from its 1,000-person news division in the past few months, closed bureaus in Chicago and Denver and slashed payments to its affiliated stations by 20 percent, or $30 million, next year. The New York Post persuaded its editorial staff earlier this year to accept $20 million in pay cuts, which meant many staffers are working four-day weeks. The newspaper's managers told the staff the alternative was to close. The National, the 10{-month-old sports newspaper that now publishes editions in 10 major markets, axed its Sunday edition earlier this month and dismissed 18 news employees, including its circulation manager. The Wall Street Journal recently announced it was closing its Philadelphia bureau and would dismiss some of the 10 employees who worked there, the first such layoffs in many years. The Journal is cutting back space devoted to news, reducing the number of planned special reports and cutting down on transfers. Business Week magazine recently said it would close its Denver and Sao Paulo, Brazil, bureaus, and eliminated 10 jobs from its staff of about 250. Others have gone much further. Murdoch Magazines closed Men's Life magazine in October after one issue, saying it was too costly in the current economic environment to build sufficient advertising and readership. Media companies are trying to raise revenue in a variety of ways. The Journal has raised its cover price by 50 percent to 75 cents, lifted subscription prices by 7.8 percent and hiked national ad rates by 6 percent. USA Today has boosted its national ad rates by 5.5 percent, while rates at the New York Times are going up 6.5 percent. National ad rates also were raised at the three newsweeklies, with Time up 6.5 percent, Newsweek up 7 percent and U.S. News & World Report up 7.9 percent. Walker said magazines also are trying to team up with other magazines to offer advertisers package deals in combinations of their publications. Newsweek recently struck such an alliance with Times Mirror Magazines, including Field & Stream and Yachting. In the most comprehensive deal to date, Chrysler Corp. signed up for a multimedia marketing package that could put Chrysler ads in Time Warner's magazines and its cable TV systems, place its vehicles in Warner Bros. films and let Chrysler dealers use Warner Bros. records or Time-Life Books as premiums in promotions to get people into the showroom.

DOC.HEAD: MCA Looks Ahead and Likes What It Sees
DOC.TEXT: MCA Inc. has seen how bright the future can be with its new owner because the entertainment conglomerate knows how gloomy the past was without it. For more than 20 years, an MCA subsidiary labored to perfect the technology behind the laser disc. MCA's Discovision Associates developed 1,400 patents at the heart of the compact disc and video disc players. But for lack of a hardware partner like pending new owner Matsushita Electrical Industrial Co., MCA and partner International Business Machines Corp. were forced last year to sell Discovision for $200 million. Buyer Pioneer Electronics Corp. of Japan took the Discovision technology and ran with it. That probably wouldn't have happened if the Matsushita deal had taken place earlier, MCA President Sidney Sheinberg said in an interview. ``Either we would have been convinced that the laservision system wasn't going to be the system of the future, or else we would have had in the family the kind of technology, the kind of skills and the kind of support that we would have needed to launch it,'' he said. MCA is banking that its new $6.6 billion marriage to Matsushita will yield a company poised to exploit any future new technologies. ``I once told somebody that the first step in planning for the future is to be sure that you're part of it,'' Sheinberg said. ``And I think by this transaction we have tried to ensure that we are part of the future.'' MCA Chairman Lew Wasserman agreed. ``I obviously think that there are many synergisms - a greater expansion of opportunities - or I wouldn't have recommended the deal to the board,'' he said. If recent blockbuster Hollywood mergers are used as a benchmark, however, MCA is not guaranteed to become an overnight world power. Time Warner Inc., strapped with close to $11 billion in debt, has not become as dominant as some believed it would, and there are rumblings the company's music division might be for sale to the right buyer. Australia's News Corp., which owns 20th Century Fox, is suffocating under $8.1 billion in debt and may sell assets. Sony Corp.'s $3.4 billion buyout of Columbia Pictures Entertainment in 1989 hasn't rattled Hollywood's rafters either, with Columbia and sister studio Tri-Star Pictures lagging. Pathe Communications Corp. has sold off so many movie rights to finance its $1.3 billion purchase of MGM-UA Communications Co. that there's scarcely any money left for growth. The distinct benefit of the MCA deal is that it leaves the company with no shortage of cash. ``This one has got one enormous advantage which is rare ... and that is that there is no financing involved,'' Sheinberg said. ``This isn't like a deal with Giancarlo Parretti,'' the head of cash-poor Pathe. Where will the MCA-Matsushita money go? ``I think the global potentials are awesome,'' Wasserman said. ``You certainly have a population of something like 800 million people in Europe, now that the curtains have come down, with very little filmed entertainment.'' He said the music business ``at the moment growing modestly in the United States but it's exploding overseas.'' Wasserman and Sheinberg, both under new five-year contracts to Matsushita, declined to say what companies they might pursue to broaden the conglomerate's reach. But it seems certain the company will pursue high-definition television. ``It could very well be that the product will be distributed in a different fashion and instead of (film) prints arriving, it could very well be that it comes from a big satellite and it's projected on high-definition television,'' Sheinberg said. Asked if he would be interested in companies such as Warner Music or PolyGram, a division of Dutch giant Phillips N.V., Wasserman replied, ``very definitely.'' There are some bothered by the trend to merge giant companies with capacities to make the hardware equipment and software such as movies, music and television shows. Arizona's Go-Video filed an antitrust lawsuit to block the merger of MCA and Matsushita, claiming they are conspiring to sabotage sales of its videocassette recorders. ``If they have control of the software they can control what kind of format it's released on,'' Go-Video lawyer Joseph Alioto said. ``If you don't own their hardware, you won't be able to see the pictures.''

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Oil Ministers Meet This Week Facing the Unexpected
DOC.TEXT: OPEC is facing the unexpected as it meets this week - plunging crude prices brought on by prospects of an oil glut and reduced military tensions in the Persian Gulf region. But analysts doubt the ministers of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will be anxious at a strategy session opening Wednesday to do much to try to hold down production and lift prices higher. ``Everybody is going to wait for the crisis to finish before taking any concrete measures,'' said Peter Bogin, associate director for oil markets at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Paris. ``They're going to be worried that prices are falling, but no one is going to take action about it,'' he said. In late August, the ministers gave the go-ahead for higher production to make up for the loss of about 4 million barrels of crude pulled off the market after Iraq invaded neighboring Kuwait. Both are OPEC members. In the four months since the occupation, speculation about the outbreak of war in the oil-rich gulf region sent prices as high as $41 a barrel. The cartel's benchmark of $21 a barrel was surpassed, with a basket of crudes monitored by the group averaging $37.04 a barrel last month. But in recent days, with the easing of tensions, prices have tumbled to levels not seen since August. At week's end, prices for North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude, were trading in the range of $25 to $26 a barrel. The benchmark American brand slipped below $28 a barrel. With surging OPEC production, storage tanks have been filled to the top. But demand has weakened, partly because of warmer-than-expected weather in the United States and other oil-importing nations. Even so, it was unlikely that OPEC ministers would be quick to reimpose their quota system and call a halt to overproduction during their winter conference at cartel headquarters in Vienna. A monitoring panel will begin work on Tuesday. ``They couldn't put the quota system back in,'' said Pierre Terzian, editor of the Paris-based newsletter Petrostrategies. ``It would mean the crisis has ended.'' Said Bogin: ``We're expecting very little. But we think there could be a lot of backroom conversation about getting ... production levels down.'' Terzian predicted, though, that the ministers would signal their intent to nail production caps back on the producers once the crisis has ended. ``They must make the market understand that there will be a halt to the glut if there is a settlement,'' he said. Indonesia's oil minister, Ginandjar Kartasasmita, acknowledged the difficulty the cartel would face in slowing down pumping. ``It is not easy to persuade all OPEC members to cut output after spending a lot to pump oil as much as they could to meet an emergency,'' he said in Jakarta last week. With the suspension of their quota system, the oil-producing nations turned up the taps. Led by heavyweight Saudi Arabia, the OPEC nations supplied nearly 23 million barrels of oil a day to the market in November, according to the International Energy Agency. Saudi Arabia, the world's largest crude exporter, pumped an estimated 7.9 million barrels a day last month, according to the agency, an arm of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. Private analysts predicted the Saudis will go even higher in December, possibly reaching as much as 8.5 million barrels a day. Before the crisis, the kingdom's production quota was 5.4 million barrels a day, giving the cartel an overall supply ceiling of 22.5 million barrels daily. In addition to Saudi Arabia, analysts said Venezuela, the United Arab Emirates, Iran, Nigeria and Libya have lifted output to help make up for the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude. OPEC members are Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Winner of Phone Company Sell-off Bid Announced
Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: An international consortium that includes Southwestern Bell will pay $1.76 billion for controlling interest in Mexico's telephone monopoly under a privatization program, the finance ministry announced Sunday. The winning bid of $2.03 a share will give the group 20.4 percent in Telefonos de Mexico, a trouble-plagued system operating about 4.1 million telephones. In addition to St. Louis-based Southwestern Bell, the winning consortium also includes Mexico's Grupo Carso and France's Cable & Radio. A bid of $1.69 million was offered by a group Acciones y Valores de Mexico, GTE Corp. of Stamford, Conn., and Telefonica de Espana. Mexico's Grupo Gentor offered nearly $1.6 billion. The government holds more than $4 billion worth of shares in the company, which is valued at roughly $8 billion. It plans to sell the remainder of its shares on national and international stock markets. The winners are supposed to post guaranteed funds by Dec. 20, according to a timetable announced earlier. Finance ministry spokesman Jack Rogosiski said all three offers ``were satisfactory.'' The choice ultimately hinged solely on price, he said. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari in September 1989 announced plans to sell off Telmex as part of a program of privatization to help revive the national economy. The effort seeks to improve phone service, expand the system and strengthen research and development. Earlier Sunday, three cabinet minister signed documents to give Telmex workers 4.4 percent of the shares. The shares are to be turned over to the workers within eight years, after a $325 million credit from the government is paid off, according to the government's Notimex news agency. Telmex had launched a three-year modernization program to help make it more attractive to buyers. The company in September signed $300 million worth of contracts with a group led by American Telephone & Telegraph Co. for a new optic-fiber cable network and terminals. Poor service by Telmex, a state monopoly since the mid-1960s, has often been blamed for helping hold back economic development in the nation of about 84 million people.
